title: Kurschner v. City of Camden Planning Commission
description: This case involves an appeal from the Planning Commission's denial of the Kurschner's application to subdivide their property.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				Robert K. and
      Sharon G. Kurschner, Appellants,
				v.
				City of Camden Planning Commission, Respondent.
			
		
	


Appeal from Kershaw County
Â L. Casey Manning, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No.Â  26414
Heard October 30, 2007 - Filed January 14,
  2008Â  
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				William
  S. Tetterton, of Camden, and Holly Palmer Beeson, of Baker Ravenel &
  Bender, of Columbia, for Appellants.
				Charles
  V.B. Cushman, III, of Camden, Weston Adams, III, Jillian M. Benson, and Walter
  Ralph Frye, III, all of McAngus Goudelock & Courie, LLC, of Columbia, for
  Respondent.
				Robert
  J. Sheheen, of Savage, Royall & Sheheen, of Camden, for Amicus Curiae Adjoining
  Landowners and the Trustees of the Legacy of Mary Boykin Chestnut.
			
		
	


CHIEF JUSTICE TOAL: Â This is an appeal from Respondent City of Camden Planning
  Commissionâ€™s (â€œthe Commissionâ€) denial of Appellants Robert and Sharon
  Kurschnerâ€™s (â€œthe Kurschnersâ€) application to subdivide their property.Â  We
  affirm.
Factual/Procedural
  Background
In 1989, the Kurschners purchased a 5.49 acre tract of
  land in the City of Camden known as Sarsfield, the former residence of Mary
  Boykin Chestnut.[1]Â 
  In 2004, the Kurschners filed an application with the Commission seeking
  approval to subdivide the property into eight lots.Â  Prior to the hearing, the
  Kurschners requested that a member of the Commission who had recently been
  elected to the South Carolina Legislature in a special election recuse herself
  from the proceeding, but the member refused the Kurschnerâ€™s request.Â  Following
  the hearing, the seven-member Commission voted unanimously to disapprove the Kurschnerâ€™s application.Â  The trial
  court affirmed the Commissionâ€™s decision.Â   
The Kurschners filed this appeal pursuant to Rule 203(d)(1)(A),
  SCACR,[2] and present the following issues for review:

	
		
			I. 
			Should the Commission member 
			have recused herself from participating in the Commissionâ€™s decision, and if so, is
  the decision therefore void?
 
		
		
			II. 
			Were the Kurschners denied their
  procedural due process rights?
 
		
		
			III.  
			
			Is the Commissionâ€™s decision 
			affected by an error of law?
		
	

Law/Analysis
I.Â  Failure to Recuse
The Kurschners
  argue that the Commission member was required to recuse herself pursuant to
  constitutional and statutory provisions prohibiting dual office holding and
  that the decision should therefore be reversed.Â  We disagree.
The South Carolina
  Code provides that â€œ[n]o member of a planning
  commission may hold an elected public office in the municipality or county from
  which appointed.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 6-29-350(B) (2004).Â  Additionally, the South Carolina Constitution prohibits
  dual office holding.Â  See S.C. Const. art. III, Â§ 24 and art. VI, Â§ 3.Â  
 
Commission member Laura Funderburk was elected to the House
  of Representatives in a special election.Â  At the time of the hearing regarding
  the Kurschnerâ€™s application, Funderburk had not yet taken the oath of office.Â  Pursuant
  to Funderburkâ€™s inquiry, the House Legislative Ethics Committee (â€œethics committeeâ€)
  issued an advisory letter opining that because there were no statutory or
  constitutional provisions providing when the winner of a special election
  begins her term of office, Funderburkâ€™s term would not begin until she took the
  oath of office.Â  The ethics committee thus concluded that she was free to
  exercise all of her duties as a member of the Commission.Â  The circuit court
  adopted the ethics committeeâ€™s position and rejected the Kurschnerâ€™s argument
  that the case should be remanded as a result of Funderburkâ€™s failure to recuse
  herself.Â   
We hold
  that Funderburk was not required to recuse herself from participating in the
  Commissionâ€™s decision. Â There are no constitutional or statutory provisions
  providing when the winner of a special election begins the term.Â  Thus, in the
  absence of such authority, the most logical point at which a representative could
  begin the term of office is upon taking the oath of office.Â  See S.C.
  Const. art. III, Â§ 26 (providing that members of the legislature must take an
  oath of office before exercising their duties of office).Â  However, even assuming
  Funderburk was holding office, the Kurschners point to no authority indicating
  that the decision is automatically void and cannot show that Funderburkâ€™s
  participation violated their due process rights.Â  Specifically, the Kurschners cannot demonstrate that
  they were prejudiced by Funderburkâ€™s participation because even without
  Funderburkâ€™s vote, there remained six votes opposing the application, as the
  Commission unanimously voted against approval.Â  See Tall Tower, Inc. v. S.C. Procurement Review
    Panel, 294
  S.C. 225, 233, 363 S.E.2d 683, 687 (1988)
  (holding that a demonstration of substantial prejudice is required
  to establish a due process claim).
For these reasons,
  we hold that the Commissionâ€™s decision should not be reversed as a result of Funderburkâ€™s participation.
II. Procedural Due Process
The Kurschners
  present a two-pronged due process argument.Â  First, the Kurschners argue that
  they were effectively deprived of due process at the hearing before the
  Commission because the Commission did not inform them of the opposing evidence
  prior to trial, considered hearsay evidence, deprived them of the opportunity
  to cross-examine adverse witnesses, and failed to allow them to conduct voir
    dire questioning of the members of the Commission.Â  Second, the Kurschners
  argue that they were deprived of due process on appeal because the
  trial courtâ€™s application of the any evidence standard of review amounted to no
  judicial review. Â We disagree as to both arguments.
Procedural due process imposes constraints on governmental
  decisions which deprive individuals of liberty or property interests within the
  meaning of the Due Process Clause of the Fifth or Fourteenth Amendment of the
  United States Constitution.Â  Mathews
    v. Eldridge, 424 U.S. 319, 332 (1976).Â  The fundamental requirements of due process include notice, an
  opportunity to be heard in a meaningful way, and judicial review. Â S.C. Const.
  art. 1, Â§ 22; Stono River Envtl. Protection Assâ€™n v. S.C. Depâ€™t
    of Health and Envtl. Control, 305 S.C. 90, 94, 406 S.E.2d 340, 342 (1991).Â  Due process does not require a
  trial-type hearing in every conceivable case of government impairment of a private
  interest. Â First Fed.
    Sav. & Loan Assâ€™n of Walterboro v. Bd. of Bank Control, 263
  S.C. 59, 65, 207 S.E.2d 801, 804 (1974)
  (quoting Cafeteria and Restaurant Workers Union v. McElroy,
  367 U.S. 886, 894 (1961)). Â Rather, due process is flexible and calls for such
  procedural protections as the particular situation demands.Â  S.C. Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Wilson, 352
  S.C. 445, 452, 574 S.E.2d 730, 733 (2002).
In our
  view, due process does not require the full gamut of rules and procedures to
  which the Kurschners claim they were entitled.Â  While due process may require a trial-type
  hearing in fact-specific, adjudicatory decisions of an administrative body, the
  power exercised by the Commission and the individual interests at stake in this
  case are very different. Â See In re Vora, 354
  S.C. 590, 582 S.E.2d 413 (2003) (involving the procedures
  required in revocation of a doctorâ€™s clinical privileges after allegations of
  deficient performance); Wilson, 352 S.C. at 456, 574 S.E.2d at
  735 (requiring additional
  procedural safeguards in a proceeding regarding child abuse allegations); Brown
    v. S.C. State Bd. of Educ., 301 S.C. 326, 391 S.E.2d 866 (1990)
  (addressing the procedures required in a proceeding concerning the revocation
  of a teacherâ€™s license).Â  Specifically, the decision to deny the Kurcshnerâ€™s
  application to subdivide their land was an exercise of discretionary authority,
  as opposed to adjudicatory power.Â  The legislature expressly granted this
  discretionary authority in the area of local planning to the Commission.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 6-29-340 (2005) (conferring municipal planning commissions
  with the power to implement and to oversee the administration of regulations
  for the growth and development of land).Â   
Regarding the requested procedural safeguards in this case, the
  Kurschners point to no authority for excluding hearsay evidence in planning
  commission decisions, nor do they provide any authority holding that
  individuals are entitled to conduct voir dire in land-use planning
  hearings.Â  In our view, the additional procedures that the Kurschners request
  would not aid the Commission in making its decision, but would greatly hinder its
  ability to make an informed and reasoned decision, as well as intrude upon a
  municipalityâ€™s statutorily-granted legislative authority.Â  Accordingly, we hold that due process does not require
  the Commission to employ these rules and procedural safeguards in making these
  types of discretionary decisions.Â  See Matthews, 424 U.S. at 335 (holding that in determining the
  process which is due, a court will consider the private interest affected by
  the proceeding, the risk of error created by the chosen procedure, and the
  countervailing governmental interest supporting challenged procedure).Â   
Furthermore, review of the procedures in this case reveals that
  the Kurschners were afforded a meaningful opportunity to be heard.Â 
  Specifically, the Commission held a public hearing where the Kurschners submitted twenty-six exhibits to support their
  application including tax information, three letters of support, title history,
  and information regarding prior subdivisions of Sarsfield.Â  Additionally, the Commission did not preclude the Kurschners from
  accessing the evidence in opposition to their application, which mostly
  consisted of public information regarding the historical significance of
  Sarsfield.Â  See Clear
    Channel Outdoor v. City of Myrtle Beach, 372 S.C. 230, 642 S.E.2d 565 (2007)
  (finding no procedural due process violation where the zoning board provided an
  applicant a meaningful opportunity to be heard regarding whether the applicant
  was entitled to a permit to replace a billboard).
Additionally,
  we believe that the Kurschnerâ€™s argument regarding judicial review is wholly
  mistaken.Â  The Kurschnerâ€™s argue that the
  trial court should have considered the substance of the evidence, and failing
  to do so deprived them of a meaningful review of the decision.Â  In our view,
  the Kurschners are essentially urging this Court to reject the any evidence
  standard of appellate review that is consistently-utilized in these types of
  cases and asking us to adopt an appellate review somewhere between a substantial
  evidence and de novo in examining decisions of a planning commission.Â  We
  decline to do so.Â   
By
  statute, the trial court must uphold the Commissionâ€™s decision unless there is
  no evidence to support it.Â  See S.C.
  Code Ann. Â§ 6-29-840 (2005) (â€œThe findings of fact by the board of appeals must
  be treated in the same manner as a finding of fact by a juryâ€); Townes
    Assocâ€™s, Ltd. v. City of Greenville, 266
  S.C. 81, 85, 221 S.E.2d 773, 775 (1976) (holding that factual findings of the
  jury will not be disturbed unless there is no evidence which reasonably
  supports the juryâ€™s findings).Â  We refuse to apply a standard of
  review different from the any evidence standard in this case, for any
  other standard of review would be contrary to the legislatureâ€™s intent in
  granting a planning commission broad discretion in this area.Â  Furthermore, this
  standard of review does not violate the Kurschnerâ€™s due process rights.Â  Fairfield Ocean Ridge, Inc. v. Town of Edisto Beach, 294 S.C. 475, 480, 366 S.E.2d 15, 18 (Ct. App.
  1988) (holding the any evidence standard of review in zoning decisions does not
  violate procedural due process). [3]
For
  the foregoing reasons, we hold that the Commissionâ€™s decision did not violate
  the Kurschnerâ€™s procedural due process rights.Â   
III. Whether the
  Commissionâ€™s Decision is Affected by an Error of Law
Finally,
  the Kurschners argue that the Commissionâ€™s decision is unsupported by the
  evidence, controlled by an error of law, and resulted in a taking without just
  compensation.Â  We disagree.Â   
A
  decision of a zoning board will not be upheld where it is based on errors of
  law, where there is no legal evidence to support it, where the board acts
  arbitrarily or unreasonably, or where, in general, the board has abused its
  discretion.Â  Peterson Outdoor Advertising v.
    City of Myrtle Beach, 327 S.C. 230, 235, 489 S.E.2d 630, 633 (1997).
In
  denying the Kurschnerâ€™s application to subdivide their property the
  Commission relied on Â§
  156.41(B)(2)(e) of the City of Camdenâ€™s Land Development Regulations, which provides
  that historic sites â€œshall be preserved to the extent consistent with the
  reasonable utilization of the site.â€Â  The Kurschners contend that this
  regulation requires that the Commission perform a balancing test to determine
  whether the proposed subdivision is an unreasonable use of the land and is
  inconsistent with its preservation.Â  The Kurschners argue that
  because the Commission failed to apply this balancing standard, the decision
  was controlled by an error of law.Â   
In
  our view, the Kurschners misinterpret this regulation.Â  The regulation merely
  directs the Commission to determine whether subdividing the property will
  negatively impact the historic value of the site.Â  The regulation does not
  mandate that the Commission apply a balancing test.Â  Byerly v. Connor, 307 S.C. 441, 444, 415 S.E.2d
  796, 799 (1992) (holding that the words of a
  regulation must be given their plain and ordinary meaning without resort to
  subtle or forced construction to limit or expand the regulationâ€™s operation).Â  The
  Commission found that subdividing Sarsfield would negatively impact the
  historical value of the property, and evidence in the record supports this
  finding.Â  Furthermore, in addition to Â§ 156.41(B)(2)(e), the Commission based
  its decision on several other regulations, as well as the City of Camdenâ€™s Comprehensive Plan.Â  Thus, the Kurschnerâ€™s argument with respect to Â§
  156.41(B)(2)(e) addresses only part of the Commissionâ€™s decision and cannot independently
  require reversal. Â 
Finally,
  any issues regarding whether this decision constituted a taking without just
  compensation may not be considered at this time.Â  This is a direct appeal from a
  decision regarding whether to uphold the Commissionâ€™s decision denying the
  Kurschnerâ€™s application to subdivide their property.Â  Any resulting issues
  raised by the operation of that decision would be not be ripe for judicial
  review at this stage, and those issues should be litigated in a separate
  action.Â  Waters
    v. S.C. Land Resources Conservation Comâ€™n, 321 S.C. 219, 227, 467 S.E.2d
  913, 917-18 (1996) (holding that a justiciable
  controversy is a real and substantial controversy which is ripe
  and appropriate for judicial determination, as distinguished from a contingent,
  hypothetical or abstract dispute).Â   
Therefore,
  we uphold the Commissionâ€™s decision because it is not controlled by an error of
  law and it is supported by evidence in the record.Â  See Â§ 6-29-840 (â€œIn determining the questions
  presented by the appeal, the court must determine only whether the decision of
  the board is correct as a matter of law.â€).
Conclusion
For the foregoing reasons, we affirm the Commissionâ€™s decision in
  denying the Kurschnerâ€™s application to subdivide their property.Â   
MOORE,
  WALLER, PLEICONES and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

[1] Chestnut is the author of A Diary from Dixie, which she wrote while
  living at Sarsfield.Â   
[2] Pursuant to Rule 203(d)(1)(A)(ii), SCACR, a party may file a direct appeal in
  this Court from â€œ[a]ny final judgment involving a challenge on state or federal
  grounds to the constitutionality of a state law or county or municipal
  ordinance where the principal issue is one of the constitutionality of the law
  or ordinance.â€
[3] The Kurschners filed a motion to argue against precedent and urge this Court to
  revisit Fairfield Ocean Ridge and hold that the any evidence standard of
  review violates procedural due process.Â  The Kurschners have failed to present
  a compelling argument to overturn that case and we therefore decline to do so.Â

description: This is a judicial disciplinary opinion in which the Court definitely suspended a magistrate.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				In the Matter of Jasper County Magistrate Donna D. Lynah, Respondent.
			
		
	


Opinion No.Â  26415
Submitted October 30, 2007 - Filed January 14, 2008 
DEFINITE SUSPENSION


	
		
			
				Lesley M.
  Coggiola, Disciplinary Counsel, and James G. Bogle, Jr., Senior Assistant
  Attorney General, both of Columbia, for Office of Disciplinary Counsel. 
				Donna D.
  Lynah, of Ridgeland, pro se.Â  
			
		
	


PER CURIAM:Â Â  In this judicial disciplinary
  matter, respondent and the Office of Disciplinary Counsel (ODC) have entered
  into an Agreement for Discipline by Consent pursuant to Rule 21, RJDE, Rule
  502, SCACR.Â  In the agreement, respondent admits misconduct and consents to the
  imposition of a sanction pursuant to Rule 7(b), RJDE, Rule 502, SCACR.Â  We
  accept the agreement and impose a ninety (90) day suspension.Â  The facts as set
  forth in the agreement are as follows.Â  
FACTS
In 1999, 2006, and 2007, the Chief
  Justice of the Supreme Court of South Carolina issued detailed orders setting
  forth specific requirements for financial accounting in all magistrate courts
  in this state.Â  Respondent attended training concerning the requirements of
  those orders, but knowingly did not comply with them in at least one or more of
  the following particulars:Â  1) she failed to insure that deposits were made as
  required by the orders and 2) she failed to insure that the bank accounts were
  reconciled monthly as required by the orders.Â  
On June 13, 2007, the Chief Magistrate
  for Jasper County held a quarterly meeting with the magistrates, including
  respondent.Â  Prior to the meeting, the Chief Magistrate had requested all
  magistrates bring certain bank reconciliation paperwork to the meeting. Â Respondent
  informed the Chief Magistrate that she did not have the reconciliations because
  her office assistant, Paula Willis, needed additional time to sort out some
  discrepancies with the deposits to the civil and criminal magistrate court
  accounts.Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
Thereafter, the Chief Magistrate asked
  another magistrate court employee, Nancy Grullon, to meet with respondent and
  Ms. Willis to review the bank accounts and assist them with the
  reconciliations.Â  When respondent informed Ms. Willis of the meeting to review
  the bank accounts, Ms. Willis became irate, left for lunch, and never returned
  to the office.Â  
Respondent then personally reviewed the
  court checking accounts and immediately realized that all deposits were not
  being made into the accounts.Â Â  Respondent and Ms. Grullon discovered a bank
  bag in Ms. Willisâ€™ desk drawer that contained cash in the amount of $1,322.00
  and non-deposited checks in the amount of $4,410.00.Â  In addition, respondent
  and Ms. Grullon found a $25.00 money order in an unopened envelope and one
  check dated November 14, 2006 in the amount of $65.00 which had not been
  deposited.Â  There was no identifying information to tie the cash to individual
  defendants or cases.Â  
An examination by county staff of
  respondentâ€™s magistrate court bank records revealed an approximate shortage of
  $15,741.82 as of July 2007.Â  An investigation into the exact amount of the
  shortage is ongoing.Â  
On or about June 23, 2007, Ms. Willis
  gave a written statement to investigators in which she stated she had been employed
  by the county for six or eight years and with the magistrateâ€™s office for the
  last three years.Â  She further stated that, within the previous six to eight
  months, she had become behind on her personal bills and, at some point, stopped
  making deposits of cash money in the magistrate court accounts and began taking
  sums from the court accounts to pay her bills.Â  Ms. Willis took full
  responsibility for the missing money stating respondent had â€œnothing to do with
  this.â€Â  
From approximately August 2006 until June
  2007, respondent had relied solely on Ms. Willis to handle court money and
  reconcile bank statements.Â  Respondent admitted to investigators that had she
  been reconciling the bank statements, this problem would have been discovered
  sooner.Â  Further, respondent admitted that she had received training but had
  not performed her duties as required.Â  Finally, respondent admitted she did not
  properly supervise Ms. Willis and did not supervise or conduct reconciliations
  of her official accounts. Â Â 
LAW
By her misconduct, respondent has
  violated the following Canons of the Code of Judicial Conduct:Â  
Canon 2 (judge shall avoid impropriety and the
    appearance of impropriety in all activities); Canon 2A (judge shall respect and
    comply with the law and shall act at all times in a manner that promotes public
    confidence in the integrity and impartiality of the judiciary); Canon 3 (judge
    shall perform the duties of judicial office diligently); Canon 3(C)(1) (judge
    shall diligently discharge her administrative responsibilities without bias or
    prejudice and maintain professional competence in judicial administration and
    should cooperate with other judges and court officials in the administration of
    court business); and Canon 3(C)(2) (judge shall require staff to observe the
    standards of fidelity and diligence that apply to the judge).Â  Â Â 
By violating the Code of Judicial Conduct, respondent has
  also violated Rule 7(a)(1) of the Rules for Judicial Disciplinary Enforcement,
  Rule 502, SCACR.Â  In addition, she violated Rule 7(a)(7), RJDE, by willfully
  violating a valid court order issued by a court of this state.Â  

CONCLUSION 

We find respondentâ€™s misconduct warrants
  a suspension from judicial duties.Â  We therefore accept the Agreement for
  Discipline by Consent and suspend respondent for ninety (90) days.Â  Within
  thirty (30) days of the date of this opinion, respondent shall pay the costs
  incurred in the investigation and prosecution of this matter by ODC and the
  Commission on Judicial Conduct.Â Â  Â 
DEFINITE SUSPENSION.
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER, PLEICONES
  and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

THE
  STATE OF
  
      
  SOUTH CAROLINA
In
  The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				The State, Respondent,
				v.
				Earle E. Morris, Jr., Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal from
  
    
  Greenville
  
  County
Â James W. Johnson, Jr.,
  Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 26418
Â Heard October 16, 2007 -
  Filed January 14, 2008
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Joel W. Collins, Jr., and Christian Stegmaier, both
  of Collins & Lacy, of
				
				Columbia,
  for Appellant.
				Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy
  Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Chief State Grand Jury Jennifer D. Evans,
  and Assistant Attorney General Deborah R.J. Shupe, all of Columbia, for
  Respondent.
			
		
	


CHIEF JUSTICE TOAL:Â  This
  is a direct appeal in a criminal case.Â  A
  jury convicted Appellant Earle E. Morris, Jr., of one count of engaging in a
  scheme to commit securities fraud and twenty-two counts of securities
  fraud.Â  On appeal, Morris questions the
  trial courtâ€™s rulings as to his motion to dismiss the indictment, the
  introduction of several pieces of testimony and evidence, and the law on
  securities fraud charged to the jury.Â  Finding no error in the trial courtâ€™s decisions on these issues, we
  affirm.
Factual/Procedural Background
This
  case involves criminal charges arising out of the collapse of Carolina Investors,
  Inc., an investment company headquartered in
  
    
  Pickens County,
  
  South Carolina.Â  Appellant Earle E. Morris, Jr.,
  (â€œAppellantâ€), joined Carolina Investors in 1972 as a member of the companyâ€™s
  board of directors, and eventually became chairman of the board.Â  Both prior to and during this time period,
  Appellant maintained an active political life.[1]Â  Upon his retirement from state government in
  1999, Appellant entered into an employment relationship with Carolina
  Investors.
Although
  the business operations of Carolina Investors changed dramatically from the
  companyâ€™s creation until it closed, the company raised capital for its
  operations in roughly the same manner throughout its existence.Â  Carolina Investors operated much like an
  uninsured savings and loan association, raising capital through the public sale
  of debentures and other debt instruments.Â  Carolina Investors initially used the funds generated from these sales
  to finance individual sales of cemetery plots.Â  The companyâ€™s services eventually expanded to include a variety of other
  lending, primarily in the sub-prime market.Â   
Since
  the companyâ€™s creation, a hallmark of Carolina Investors was a feature known as
  â€œthe fifteen minute rule.â€Â  This rule
  operated to allow investors to redeem their debentures at any time prior to
  maturity, but provided for a reduced rate of interest upon such
  redemption.Â  According to the company, an
  investor could redeem a debenture at any time and have their money â€œin fifteen
  minutes.â€Â   
In
  1991, Carolina Investors became a wholly owned subsidiary of National Railway
  Utilization Corporation, which eventually became the company HomeGold,
  Inc.Â  Roughly four years later, Carolina
  Investors ceased its external lending activities.Â  Although the company continued to raise funds
  by selling debentures, Carolina Investors simply transferred these funds
  directly to HomeGold or its other subsidiaries.Â  HomeGold and its subsidiaries primarily used these funds to expand their
  business operations and pay operating expenses.Â  Although the companies were profitable at one time, HomeGold began to
  experience substantial operating losses in 1998.Â  These losses continued to mount, and when
  HomeGold failed to transfer funds sufficient to cover investorsâ€™ requests to
  withdraw the balance of their debentures from Carolina Investors, the
  businesses closed.
The
  criminal charges that form the basis of the instant case arose primarily out of
  Appellantâ€™s conduct in the year immediately preceding the collapse of Carolina
  Investors and HomeGold.Â  Specifically,
  the State alleged that in the waning time period of Carolina Investorsâ€™
  operation, Appellant had a great deal of information regarding the dire
  financial condition of HomeGold and the growing probability that HomeGold would
  never be able to repay its debt to Carolina Investors.Â  Rumors of the companiesâ€™ continued viability
  began to surface with increasing regularity, and the State alleged that as
  individual customers contacted Carolina Investors with concerns, either in
  person or over the phone, Carolina Investors employees systematically referred
  these investors to Appellant, who then misled the investors with false
  assurances of current and future profitability.Â  The State also alleged that in some circumstances, customers were able
  to redeem debentures without having first spoken with Appellant, and that
  Appellant would thereafter personally contact these individuals and attempt to
  persuade them to re-invest with Carolina Investors.Â  According to the State, Appellantâ€™s
  misrepresentations caused investors to leave funds on deposit that they would
  otherwise have withdrawn and persuaded investors to deposit additional funds or
  re-invest withdrawn funds with the company.Â  The State alleged that Appellantâ€™s actions were in furtherance of a
  scheme to keep a steady stream of money flowing to HomeGold.
At
  trial, Appellant asserted that his projections to investors were not
  intentional misrepresentations, but were instead genuinely held sentiments
  based upon projections received from executives at HomeGold or their
  professional consultants.Â  Appellant
  further argued that his position as chairman of Carolina Investorsâ€™ board of
  directors was merely an illusory position, and that he was kept in the dark as
  to the companyâ€™s bleak financial situation.Â  The jury ultimately convicted Appellant of one count of engaging in a
  scheme to commit securities fraud and twenty-two individual counts of
  securities fraud. Â The trial court
  sentenced Appellant to forty-four months imprisonment, and this appeal
  followed.
This
  Court certified the case from the court of appeals pursuant to Rule 204(b),
  SCACR, and Appellant presents multiple issues for this Courtâ€™s review:
	
		
			I.  
			Should Appellant have been 
			granted immunity as a result of his pre-trial statement to 
			representatives of the
  
    
  South Carolina
  securities commissioner?
 
		
		
			II.
			Did the trial court err in 
			charging the jury that criminal securities fraud could include 
			conduct exhibiting â€œextreme recklessness,â€ â€œsevere recklessness,â€ 
			and â€œextreme indifference?â€
 
		
		
			III. 
			Did the trial court err in 
			allowing certain testimony from the Stateâ€™s corporations and 
			securities law expert? 
 
		
		
			IV. 
			Did the trial court err in 
			disallowing testimony from Appellantâ€™s legal ethics expert?
 
		
		
			V.
			Did the trial court err in 
			excluding the report prepared by the bankruptcy courtâ€™s examiner?
 
		
		
			VI. 
			Did the trial court err in 
			denying Appellantâ€™s motion to dismiss the indictment?
 
		
		
			VII. 
			Did the trial court err in 
			denying Appellantâ€™s request for a continuance?
		
	


Law/Analysis

I.  Immunity from Prosecution
Appellant
  argues that the trial court should have granted him immunity as a result of his
  pre-trial statement to representatives of the
  
    
  South Carolina securities commissioner.Â  We disagree.
In State v. Thrift, we held that the South
  Carolina Constitution requires that a person compelled to provide the
  government with self-incriminating testimony be granted immunity from any
  prosecution for a transaction or offense to which the personâ€™s testimony
  relates.Â  312 S.C. 282, 301, 440 S.E.2d
  341, 351 (1994) (interpreting S.C. Const. art. I, Â§ 12 to require transactional
  immunity for compelled testimony).Â  In Thrift, we addressed the question of
  immunity in the context of compelled testimony before the State Grand
  Jury.Â 
      
      
      Id.
  at 296, 440 S.E.2d at 349.Â  Although this
  Court affirmed the trial courtâ€™s decision dismissing the indictments against
  several defendants on a number of alternative grounds, we nevertheless held
  that the then-applicable immunity statute providing simply for use immunity
  failed to comport with the Constitutionâ€™s demands.Â 
      
      
      Id. at 301,
  440 S.E.2d at 351.
Appellant
  asserts Thrift requires that he be
  granted immunity from prosecution in this case.Â  Specifically, Appellant argues that the Attorney General used his
  statutory authority as securities commissioner to compel Appellant to offer self-incriminating
  testimony.[2]Â  Though intriguing at first blush, this
  argument is not supported by the facts of the instant case.
Thriftâ€™s
  compulsion requirement supplies the first hurdle that Appellantâ€™s argument
  cannot negotiate.Â  More specifically, Appellant
  was not compelled to appear before the securities commissioner, nor was
  Appellant compelled to answer any questions before the commissionerâ€™s
  representatives.Â  The record instead reflects
  that very shortly after the collapse of Carolina Investors and HomeGold, the
  securities commissioner issued a subpoena duces
    tecum requesting that Carolina Investors, the president of the company, and
  the chairman of the board supply documents and records relating to the business.Â  We find it instructive that this subpoena was
  not directed to any individuals, nor did it request any personal appearances.Â  
 
Although
  Appellant argued in testimony to the trial court that he was â€œcompelledâ€ to
  attend the meeting with the representatives of the securities commissioner,
  Appellant later testified that he advised a member of the securities
  commissionerâ€™s staff that he desired to personally meet and discuss the
  situation, as he and other representatives of the company had often done in the
  past.Â  Appellant no doubt felt a strong
  desire to appear before the securities commissioner to provide information and
  be of assistance, but we think that a strong desire to provide assistance
  cannot be the equivalent of compulsion.Â  See Thrift, 312 S.C. at 297, 440 S.E.2d
  at 349 (speaking of compelled testimony as testimony wrung from a person by
  force).Â  Because there is no evidence
  that the securities commissioner compelled Appellantâ€™s testimony, Appellantâ€™s
  argument based on Thrift is
  inapposite.
To
  achieve his desired result through an alternate route, Appellant makes the
  novel argument that in order to avoid Thriftâ€™s
  rule regarding immunity, the securities commissioner was required to inform
  Appellant of his constitutional right against self-incrimination and obtain a valid
  waiver of that right prior to questioning Appellant.Â  Again, we disagree.
Appellantâ€™s
  argument here presumes too much.Â  Essentially, Appellant argues that the securities commissioner may not
  place a person under oath without advising the person of his constitutional
  rights, and that the failure to do so should require a de facto finding of
  compulsion.Â  Though the most prudent
  practice in any investigative scenario would always be for law enforcement to
  advise any person from whom information is sought of the individualâ€™s constitutional
  rights, the Constitution does not require such prudence.Â  The law instead requires only that the government
  apprise a person of the constitutional privilege against self-incrimination when
  the person is subjected to interrogation while in the custody of law
  enforcement.Â  See e.g. State v. Evans, 354 S.C. 579, 583, 582 S.E.2d 407, 409-410
  (2003) (citing Miranda v. Arizona,
  384
  
        
    U.S.
  436, 444 (1966)).Â  Accordingly, we focus
  our inquiry, as did the trial court, on whether Appellant was in custody when
  he gave his statement to the securities commissionerâ€™s representatives.
In
  our view, Appellant was not in custody when he gave his statement to
  representatives of the securities commissioner.Â  The evidence illustrates that Appellant was not ordered to appear at the
  meeting, there is no evidence that Appellant was a suspect of any crime at this
  point, and there is no evidence that Appellant was prohibited from leaving at
  any point.Â  Although the evidence
  illustrates that the interview occurred at the securities division in the
  Attorney Generalâ€™s office, there is no evidence as to who requested that the
  meeting occur there, nor is there evidence that the purpose of this meeting was
  to elicit incriminating statements from Appellant.Â  Because Appellant cannot point to any factors
  demonstrating that he gave his statement while in the governmentâ€™s custody, the
  securities commissioner was under no obligation to advise Appellant of his
  constitutional rights.
As a
  final immunity-based argument, Appellant argues that the State impermissibly
  pursued criminal charges against him under the guise of the securities
  commissionerâ€™s administrative investigation into the collapse of Carolina
  Investors. We disagree.
Appellant
  draws on both this Courtâ€™s precedent and federal precedent in support of his
  argument.Â  In State v. Quattlebaum, 338 S.C. 441, 527 S.E.2d 105 (2000), the
  trial court refused to disqualify a circuit solicitorâ€™s office from prosecuting
  a defendant where several sheriffâ€™s officers and a deputy solicitor monitored
  and recorded a privileged communication between the defendant and his
  attorney.Â  This Court reversed, and in
  doing so, the Court held that deliberate prosecutorial misconduct raises an
  irrebuttable presumption of prejudice.Â 
      
      
      Id.
  at 449, 527 S.E.2d at 109.Â  The Court
  noted that â€œ[t]he participation at trial of a prosecutor who has eavesdropped
  on the accused and his attorney tarnishes us all.â€Â 
      
      
      Id.
Similarly,
  in United States v. Kordel, 397
  
        
    U.S.
  1, 12-13
  (1970), the United States Supreme Court rejected the argument that a
  governmentâ€™s inquiry directed against a corporate defendant ought to per se
  immunize a corporationâ€™s directors from subsequent criminal prosecution.Â  Speaking where the issue was parallel
  investigations of a food company by the Food and Drug Administration and the
  United States Attorneyâ€™s office, the court noted that while it is clear that
  the government may not â€œuse evidence against a defendant in a criminal case
  which has been coerced from him,â€ the occurrence of parallel civil and criminal
  investigations does not, absent extraordinary circumstance, violate a
  defendantâ€™s rights to due process.Â 
      
      
      Id.
We
  hold that both Quattlebaum and Kordel are totally inapplicable to the
  instant case.Â  There has been absolutely
  no showing of any prosecutorial misconduct in this matter, and Appellant has
  not demonstrated that his prosecution is unconstitutional, improper, or that
  the government pursued a civil action or investigation solely to obtain
  evidence for a criminal prosecution.Â  Although
  it is likely that information conveyed in the statement to the securities
  commissionerâ€™s representatives ultimately assisted in the Stateâ€™s criminal
  investigation, there is no evidence that the State contemplated a criminal
  investigation of Appellant at the time of the meeting.[3]Â  It is not impossible for us to envision
  circumstances that might raise concerns when combined with the fact that the
  
      
  South Carolina official
  vested with the power to institute civil investigations in securities matters
  also serves as the Stateâ€™s chief criminal prosecuting officer.Â  But in this case, there is simply no support
  for any analogy or purported similarity between the instant case and Quattlebaum or Kordel.
For
  these reasons, we hold that the trial court did not err in determining that
  Appellant is not entitled to immunity from prosecution.
II.  Jury
  Charges
Appellant
  argues that the trial court erred in charging the jury that criminal securities
  fraud can include conduct exhibiting â€œextreme recklessness,â€ â€œsevere
  recklessness,â€ and â€œextreme indifference.â€Â  More specifically, Appellant argues that a conviction for criminal
  securities fraud requires a finding of scienter, and that the trial courtâ€™s
  charges did not instruct the jury accordingly.Â  We disagree.
As a
  primary matter, Appellant is mistaken in his characterization of the trial
  courtâ€™s charges.Â  In addition to charging
  the jury that it could find that Appellant violated the securities laws if it
  found that Appellant knowingly committed misconduct, the court charged the jury
  that it could convict Appellant if it found that he engaged in conduct â€œwhich
  presents a danger of misleading buyers or sellers that is either known to
  [Appellant] or is so obvious that [Appellant] must have been aware of it.â€[4]Â  Stated differently, the court charged that in
  order to support a conviction, the jury needed to find that Appellant
  intentionally misled investors, or that Appellant knew that there was a danger
  that his conduct would mislead investors.Â Â Â   
The
  trial courtâ€™s charges accurately characterized the mental state required for a
  criminal conviction for securities fraud in
  
      
  South Carolina.Â  Where a statute does not specify that
  criminal liability is to be imposed based upon graduated levels of intent, we
  are extremely reluctant to draw such distinctions.Â  Furthermore, we believe that predicating
  criminal liability on a stricter standard than this would unnecessarily
  frustrate the purpose of the securities fraud statutes.Â  In S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 35-1-1210 and 35-1-1590 (Supp.
  2004), the Legislature saw fit to criminalize the making of untrue or
  misleading statements in connection with the offer, sale, or purchase of securities,
  and we can discern no reasonable basis for weakening this prohibition by not
  imposing criminal liability in the situation where a person makes statements
  that he or she knows presents a danger of misleading individual investors.Â  Prevention of this type of conduct strikes at
  the heart of the intended purpose of the securities laws.[5]
A
  review of the evidence presented at trial is instructive.Â  The record reflects that HomeGold lost over
  $300 million from 1998 until the companies closed.Â  During this same time, the record reflects
  that HomeGoldâ€™s inter-company debt to Carolina Investors grew from about
  $304,000 to over $275 million.Â  At trial,
  the State introduced evidence that Appellant attended board meetings where
  officers discussed HomeGoldâ€™s enormous losses and the tremendously increasing
  inter-company debt.Â  The State introduced
  evidence that Appellant attended meetings where auditors hired by the company discussed
  the grave circumstances caused by the lack of positive cash flow to HomeGold
  and the accompanying likelihood that HomeGold would never repay its debt to
  Carolina Investors.Â  The State introduced
  evidence that Appellant discussed these circumstances with his fellow board
  members, and that Appellant attended meetings where the parties explored the
  issues of bankruptcy or a convervatorship.Â  Finally, the State introduced evidence that despite being fully aware of
  the dire situation of the company, Appellant used his reputation to aggressively
  attract and retain customers for Carolina Investors, and that Appellant was
  financially rewarded based upon his effectiveness in preventing massive
  requests to redeem debentures.
Witness
  at trial testified that when confronted with specific questions regarding
  individual investments and the financial situation of the company, Appellant
  responded â€œI see the numbers and your money is safe,â€ that there was no way
  that anyone was going to lose any money, and that there was a lawsuit against
  another company for putting out false information about Carolina
  Investors.Â  Additional witnesses
  testified that Appellant told customers that Carolina Investors had been â€œsold
  to a company in California,â€ that Carolina Investors was â€œas solid as the floor
  weâ€™re standing on,â€ that the company was â€œas solid as the rock of Gibraltar,â€
  and that â€œmoney here is as good as if it were gold.â€Â  This case was not, as Appellant suggests, an
  example of looking backwards at his conduct through the often distorting lens
  of hindsight.Â  Instead, the theory of the
  Stateâ€™s case revolved around evidence showing what Appellant said to twenty-two
  specific investors versus what Appellant knew to be the financial reality.Â  If the inclusion of the term recklessness,
  despite the trial courtâ€™s detailed definition of the term, could have
  introduced any ambiguity into the juryâ€™s understanding of the law, it had no
  effect on this case.Â  The instant case
  did not deal with reckless conduct.
Accordingly,
  we hold that the trial court did not err in charging the jury as to the mental
  state required for a criminal conviction of securities fraud.
III.  The
  Stateâ€™s Expert
At
  trial, the State offered Gregory B. Adams as an expert in corporate and
  securities laws.Â  Appellant argues that
  Adams was not qualified to opine on issues of corporate and securities laws in
  
  South Carolina because Adams is not licensed to practice
  law in
  
  
  South Carolina.Â  We disagree.
The
  qualification of a witness as an expert is a matter largely within the trial
  courtâ€™s discretion and will not be reversed absent an abuse of that
  discretion.Â  State v. Myers, 301 S.C. 251, 255, 391 S.E.2d 551, 554 (1990).Â  Generally, defects in the amount and quality
  of an expertâ€™s education or experience go to the weight to be accorded the
  expertâ€™s testimony and not to its admissibility.Â 
      
      
      Id.Â  In
  
      
  South
  
  Carolina, expert
  testimony is admissible where the testimony will assist the trier of fact in
  understanding the evidence or determining a fact in issue.Â  Rule 702, SCRE.
Despite
  Appellantâ€™s argument to the contrary, the status of
  
  Adamsâ€™ law license is completely irrelevant to his qualification as an expert. Â The evidentiary rule governing the
  qualifications of experts says nothing about professional licensing
  requirements, and a licensing requirement seems wholly incompatible with Rule
  702â€™s operational framework.Â  At the time
  of trial, Adams had been a law professor at the
  
      
  University of
  
  South
  Carolina for more than twenty-five years, with
  experience teaching corporate and securities law classes.Â  Furthermore, the record reflects that Adams
  served as one of the authors of the 1988 South Carolina Business Corporations
  Act, and that
  
  Adams serves as one of the
  co-authors of the primary practice manual on corporate law used in this
  state.Â  In light of this evidence, the
  trial court clearly did not abuse its discretion in qualifying
  
  Adams as an expert on corporate and securities laws. [6] 

Appellant
  next contends that Adamsâ€™ testimony was contrary to the law of
  
      
  South Carolina and
  should have been excluded.Â  We disagree.

  
  
  Adams testified that in certain contexts, statements that are often associated with
  unactionable puffery can constitute fraudulent misstatements in violation of
  the securities laws.Â  Although Appellant
  may be correct that, in general, â€œprojections of future performance not worded
  as guarantees are not actionable under securities laws,â€
      
  Adams
  did not testify to the contrary.Â  Instead,
  
  Adams testified that
  commercial puffery, by definition, excludes statements that are material to
  investors, and that the atmosphere in which a statement is made bears on its
  materiality.Â  Because Appellant does not
  accurately describe
  
  Adamsâ€™ testimony,
  Appellantâ€™s argument is unpersuasive.
As a
  final point on this issue, Appellant argues that the trial court improperly
  allowed
  
  Adams to opine on the ultimate issue
  in this case, which is whether Appellant engaged in fraudulent conduct.Â  Again, we disagree.
This
  Courtâ€™s rules provide that â€œ[t]estimony in the form of an opinion . . .
  otherwise admissible is not objectionable because it embraces an ultimate issue
  to be decided by the trier of fact.â€Â  Rule 704, SCRE.Â  In this case, the
  State concluded its examination of
  
  Adams by
  presenting a series of hypothetical situations and asking whether certain
  actions in those hypotheticals would be illegal. Â Although this testimony arguably involved the
  ultimate issue in the instant case, this case required the jury to analyze
  facts and circumstances as they existed in a complex business environment, and
  the trial court determined that expert testimony would assist the jury in
  making its determinations.Â  For this
  reason, this case differs substantially from the expert testimony cases upon
  which Appellant relies.[7]
For
  the foregoing reasons, we affirm the trial courtâ€™s decision regarding the
  qualification of the Stateâ€™s corporate and securities law expert and the
  admission of the expertâ€™s testimony.
IV.  Exclusion
  of Appellantâ€™s Ethics Expert
Appellant
  argues that the trial court improperly excluded the testimony of his expert in
  legal ethics and conflicts of interest.Â  We disagree.
The admission or exclusion of evidence is left to the sound
  discretion of the trial court, and the courtâ€™s decision will not be reversed
  absent an abuse of discretion.Â  State v. Gaster, 349 S.C. 545, 557, 564
  S.E.2d 87, 93 (2002).Â  An abuse of
  discretion occurs when the trial courtâ€™s decision is based upon an error of law
  or upon factual findings that are without evidentiary support. Â State v.
    Irick, 344 S.C. 460, 464, 545 S.E.2d 282, 284 (2001).
At trial, Appellant offered attorney Desa Ballard as an
  expert in legal ethics and conflicts of interest.Â  Through Ballard, Appellant sought to offer
  testimony as to the conflict of interest HomeGoldâ€™s officers and corporate
  attorneys experienced by simultaneously representing Carolina Investors in
  various capacities.[8]Â  Although the trial court qualified Ballard as
  an expert, the court held that her testimony as to conflicts of interest was irrelevant,
  and alternatively, that the testimony would confuse the issues in the case.
The trial court did not abuse its discretion in excluding
  Ballardâ€™s testimony.Â  This Court is concerned
  by the apparent conflict of interest created by the fact that a single law firm
  attempted to provide legal services to two companies whose relationship, given
  the financial characteristics of the situation, was anything but symbiotic; and
  additionally by the fact that a principal of the law firm served as an officer
  on the board of the parent corporation.Â  But assuming, without deciding, that a conflict existed here, Appellant
  cannot demonstrate how any attorneyâ€™s action or inaction caused him to believe
  that it was advisable to mislead investors.Â  Similarly, Appellant points to no evidence indicating that any attorney
  was knowledgeable of his conduct, particularly as to Appellantâ€™s statements to
  individual investors.Â  Accordingly, the trial
  court did not abuse its discretion in concluding that issue of a law firmâ€™s conflict
  of interest was irrelevant and confusing with respect to the issues presented
  in this case.Â   
For these reasons, we hold that the trial court did not err
  in excluding the testimony of Appellantâ€™s expert in legal ethics and conflicts
  of interest.Â   
V.  Exclusion
  of the Bankruptcy Examinerâ€™s Report
Appellant
  argues that the trial court incorrectly excluded the report prepared by the
  bankruptcy examiner in the federal bankruptcy litigation involving Carolina
  Investors and HomeGold from evidence.Â  Specifically,
  Appellant argues that the bankruptcy examinerâ€™s report was admissible under the
  public records and reports exception to this Courtâ€™s general rule excluding
  hearsay evidence.Â  See Rules 802 & 803(8), SCRE.Â  We disagree.
Appellantâ€™s
  argument regarding the public records or reports exception to the hearsay rule
  is, in our view, misguided.Â  Rule 803(8),
  SCRE, specifically provides that â€œinvestigative notes involving opinions,
  judgments, or conclusions are not admissible.â€Â  An examination of the bankruptcy examinerâ€™s report reveals that the
  report contains a great deal of investigative opinions, legal analysis, and
  potential conclusions.[9]Â  For these reasons, we hold that the trial
  court correctly concluded that the bankruptcy examinerâ€™s report was outside the
  scope of the public records and reports exception.
Appellant
  makes a second argument that the â€œrule of completeness,â€ see Rule 106, SCRE, required the trial court to admit the
  examinerâ€™s report into evidence, but we believe this argument is similarly
  flawed.Â  As the trial court made clear, it
  did not admit the examinerâ€™s report or any part of the examinerâ€™s report into
  evidence. Â Furthermore, the State did not
  offer any testimony, expert or otherwise, that drew from the examinerâ€™s report or
  any part thereof.Â  Because the trial
  court never admitted any portion of the examinerâ€™s report, Appellantâ€™s rule of
  completeness argument is inapposite.
Accordingly,
  we hold that the trial court did not err in excluding the bankruptcy examinerâ€™s
  report.
VI.  Dismissal
  of the Indictment as Defective
Appellant
  argues that the trial court incorrectly denied his motion to dismiss the
  indictment as defective.Â  Specifically,
  Appellant argues that the conduct set forth in the indictment does not fall
  within the purview of the criminal statutes the State charged him with
  violating because all alleged misstatements regarding Carolina Investorsâ€™
  financial health and business operations were to pre-existing customers and not
  prospective customers.Â  We disagree.
Appellant
  takes far too narrow a view of the statuteâ€™s application.Â  Specifically, Appellantâ€™s argument overlooks
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 35-1-20(13)(a) and (b) (Supp. 2004), providing that â€œsaleâ€
  means every contract for the sale of, contract to sell, or contract for the
  disposition of a security or interest in a security for value; and that an
  â€œofferâ€ includes every attempt or offer to dispose of, or solicitation of an
  offer to buy, a security or interest in a security for value.Â  Because Carolina Investors customers had the
  option of disposing of their debentures prior to maturity, there is no
  reasonable way to view Appellantâ€™s conversations with customers as not relating
  to offers to dispose of securities.Â  In
  fact, the only arguable purpose of Appellantâ€™s statements to customers was to
  prevent the disposition of securities.
For
  the foregoing reasons, we hold that the trial court did not err in denying
  Appellantâ€™s motion to dismiss the indictment as defective.
VII.  Appellantâ€™s
  Request for a Continuance
Appellant
  argues that the trial court incorrectly denied his request for a
  continuance.Â  We disagree.
The
  trial courtâ€™s denial of a motion for a continuance will not be disturbed on
  appeal absent a clear abuse of discretion.Â  State v. McMillian, 349 S.C.
  17, 21, 561 S.E.2d 602, 604 (2002).Â  In
  support of his argument that the trial court abused its discretion in denying
  his request, Appellant argues that his trial was premature and that had the
  court granted a continuance, Appellant would have been able to demonstrate that
  he was a victim of an intentional campaign of deception by HomeGold executives.
  Appellant asserts that he did not call several potential witnesses who would
  have corroborated his theory of the case because these witnesses had criminal
  trials pending and would have asserted their Fifth Amendment rights.
Appellant
  cannot demonstrate that he suffered any prejudice as a result of being forced
  to proceed to trial rather than being granted a continuance.[10]Â  At trial, Appellant presented a great deal of
  evidence, including his personal testimony, regarding what he alleged to be
  evidence of HomeGoldâ€™s scheme to hide financial data from Carolina Investors
  officials.Â  Furthermore, Appellant
  presented the testimony of several co-workers to corroborate his â€œkept in the
  darkâ€ defense.Â  Importantly, Appellant
  cannot demonstrate that the grant of a continuance would have in any way
  affected the Fifth Amendment considerations he raises in support of his
  argument.Â  In our view, the grant of a
  continuance would have generated no such effect.
As a
  housekeeping matter on this issue, it is instructive to note that this Courtâ€™s
  evidentiary rules speak to the subject of continuances in the context of
  unavailable witnesses.Â  Rule 7(b),
  SCRCrimP, provides:

	No
  motion for continuance of trial shall be granted on account of the absence of a
  witness without the oath of the party, his counsel, or agent to the following
  effect: the testimony of the witness is material to the support of the action
  or defense of the party moving; the motion is not intended for delay, but is
  made solely because he cannot go safely to trial without such testimony; and
  has made use of due diligence to procure the testimony of the witness or of
  such other circumstances as will satisfy the court that his motion is not
  intended for delay.

At trial, Appellant did not
  demonstrate any of the above-described hardships in support of his request for
  a continuance.Â  Furthermore, in light of
  the evidence introduced at trial, any testimony from unavailable witnesses or other
  unavailable evidence would likely have been cumulative.Â  Accordingly, there is no indication that
  Appellant would have been able to make a successful argument for a continuance
  based upon Rule 7(b).
Accordingly, we hold that the trial court did not abuse its
  discretion in denying Appellantâ€™s request for a continuance.
Conclusion
For
  the foregoing reasons, we affirm Appellantâ€™s conviction and sentence.[11]

  
  
  
  MOORE, WALLER and
    BEATTY, JJ., concur.Â  PLEICONES, J.,
    concurring in a separate opinion.
JUSTICE PLEICONES:Â  I concur in the majorityâ€™s
  decision to affirm appellantâ€™s convictions and sentences, but write separately
  because I view several of the issues differently than does the majority.Â  I have addressed the issues in the same
  order.  
I agree that appellant was not entitled to immunity because
  he was not compelled to provide the State with self-incriminating
  information.Â  State v. Thrift, 312
  S.C. 282, 440 S.E.2d 341 (1994).Â  I do
  not join that part of the majority opinion which advises investigators to
  impart Miranda warnings where they are not otherwise required
I agree that the jury instruction given in this case did
  not misstate the scienter requirement in a securities fraud prosecution.Â  See State v. Thompkins, 263
  S.C. 472, 211 S.E.2d 549 (1975)(knowingly means actual knowledge, but one can
  not avoid â€œknowingâ€ by shutting oneâ€™s eyes to what would otherwise be
  obvious).Â  Unlike the majority, I would
  not find that a review of the evidence is in order.Â  As I view appellantâ€™s complaint, it is not
  that the charge was not warranted by the evidence, but rather that it misstated
  the scienter requirement.Â  Finally, I
  would not engage in the harmless error analysis undertaken at the conclusion of
  section II of the opinion, as I would find no error in the charge given.[12] 
 
As to the testimony of the Stateâ€™s expert, I agree with the
  majority that we should affirm the trial courtâ€™s ruling that the expert was
  qualified.Â  See Smith v.
    Haynesworth, 322 S.C. 433, 472 S.E.2d 612 (1996).
As to appellantâ€™s contention that the trial court erred in
  not permitting his expert to testify to a law firmâ€™s alleged conflict of
  interest, I would affirm as the proffered testimony was simply not
  relevant.Â  Rule 402, SCRE.
I agree that the Bankruptcy Examinerâ€™s Report was properly
  excluded from evidence.  
I agree that the trial judge did not err in refusing to
  dismiss the indictment, which is couched in the language of the statute. E.g., State v. Means, 367 S.C. 374, 626 S.E.2d 348 (2006) qualified on other grounds Talley v. State, 371 S.C. 535,
  640 S.E.2d 878 (2007).Â  In my view,
  appellantâ€™s contention that the evidence did not show a statutory violation is
  one to be addressed at trial at the directed verdict stage, not a defect
  apparent on the face of the indictment warranting the indictmentâ€™s dismissal.
Finally, I agree with the majorityâ€™s decision to affirm the
  denial of appellantâ€™s continuance request, and to affirm the denial of his
  directed verdict motion.[13]
For the reasons given above, I concur in the majorityâ€™s decision
  affirming appellantâ€™s convictions and sentences.

[1] Appellant served in the South Carolina House
  of Representatives from 1951-1955, in the South Carolina Senate from 1955-1970,
  as the Lieutenant Governor of South Carolina from 1971-1975, and as Comptroller
  General from 1976-1999.Â   
[2] S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 35-1-20(1) (Supp. 2004) provides
  that the Attorney General of South Carolina serves as the ex officio securities
  commissioner.
In 2005, the Legislature comprehensively
  amended
  
  South Carolinaâ€™s
  securities laws.Â  See Act No. 110, 2005 S.C. Acts 681 (â€œthe
  
      
  South Carolina Uniform Securities Act of
  2005â€).Â  In doing so, the Legislature
  reorganized a great deal of the statutes at issue here.Â  Though the definitional statute now appears
  in a different code section, see S.C.
  Code Ann. Â§ 35-1-102(28) (Supp. 2006), this reorganization does not appear to
  have substantially altered the relevant statutory language.
[3] The meeting occurred roughly two weeks after
  Carolina Investors closed, and the State Grand Jury indicted Appellant
  approximately nine months later.
[4] This latter portion of the charge
  represents the trial courtâ€™s definition of the term recklessness.
[5] In fact, the statutory scheme expressly forecloses Appellantâ€™s argument.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 35-1-501 cmt. 6 (Supp. 2006) (providing that the
  culpability required to be pled and proven is addressed in the enforcement
  statute); see also S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  35-1-508 cmts. 2, 6 (Supp. 2006) (providing that both the current and former
  versions of the Code impose criminal liability for securities fraud when a
  person acts intentionally in the sense that the person is aware of what he or
  she is doing and that â€œ[p]roof of evil motive or intent to violate the law or
  knowledge that the law was violated is not requiredâ€).
[6] Appellant relies in part on S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  40-22-20 (22) (Supp. 2006) to support his policy-based argument that an expert
  on South Carolina law should be required to be licensed to practice law in this
  state.Â  Although Appellant correctly
  points out that Â§ 40-22-20(22) defines the practice of engineering to include
  offering expert testimony, Appellant overlooks this Courtâ€™s decision in Baggerly v. CSX Transp., Inc., 370 S.C.
  362, 374-75, 635 S.E.2d 97, 103-04 (2006), where this Court declined to interpret
  the practice of engineering statute to preclude the offering of expert
  testimony by a person not licensed as a professional engineer in South
  Carolina.  
[7] In Dawkins
  v. Fields, 354 S.C. 58, 580 S.E.2d 433 (2003), this Court held that the
  trial court properly refused to consider an expert affidavit filed in response
  to a summary judgment motion where the affidavit largely contained only legal
  opinions, conclusions, and no factual support.Â  Similarly, in Oâ€™Quinn v. Beach
    Assocs., 272 S.C. 95, 249 S.E.2d 734 (1978), the trial court refused to
  permit an expert to opine on whether an offer of commercial services would
  constitute the offering of investment contracts under federal law.Â  Affirming the trial courtâ€™s decision, this
  Court held that the testimony was offered to establish a conclusion of law
  within the exclusive province of the court, and thus was properly
  excluded.Â 
      
      
      Id.
  at 107, 249 S.E.2d at 740.Â   
[8] The law firm Wyche, Burgess, Freeman, and
  Parham served as HomeGoldâ€™s corporate counsel and also prepared Carolina
  Investorsâ€™ annual prospectus for approval by the securities commissioner.Â  Attorney C. Thomas Wyche served as an officer
  on HomeGoldâ€™s board of directors.Â   
[9] By way of example, the report provides that
  â€œ[m]anagement and its advisors knew that their investor customers would equate
  [Carolina Investors] with a bank,â€ and â€œit is clear that the game plan was to
  knowingly gamble the money of unsophisticated creditors.â€Â  The report also offers numerous conclusions
  beginning with the preface â€œthere is sufficient evidence for a finder of fact
  to conclude.â€Â  Additionally, the examiner
  opines on the applicability of several potential legal defenses, and opines
  specifically that the business judgment rule would not protect the officers and
  directors of Carolina Investors.Â   
[10] The State Grand Jury indicted Appellant in
  January 2004, and Appellantâ€™s trial occurred during November 2004.Â   
[11] As an eighth issue on appeal, Appellant argues that the trial court erred in
  denying his motion for a directed verdict.Â  We affirm the trial courtâ€™s decision on this issue pursuant to Rule 220(b)(1), SCACR, and the following
  authority: State v. Weston, 367 S.C.
  279, 292-93, 625 S.E.2d 641, 648 (2006) (providing that a trial court examines
  a request for a directed verdict based on the existence or nonexistence of
  evidence, and that if there is any direct or substantial circumstantial
  evidence reasonably tending to prove the defendantâ€™s guilt, the case must be submitted
  to the jury).
[12]This
  is not to suggest that I would endorse the instruction as a model charge. 
 
[13] I
  note that the directed verdict is contested not on the basis that the State
  failed to prove in some counts that there was a â€œsaleâ€ of securities as defined
  by the statute, but on the ground that the State failed to prove appellant
  possessed the requisite intent.

text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				Nitus Joanne
      Linog, Appellant,
				v.
				Mark Yampolsky,
      D.D.S., and Eloise Bradham, M.D., Respondents.
			
		
	


Appeal from Charleston County
Â Mikell R. Scarborough, Master-in-Equity
Opinion No. 26419
Heard October 17, 2007 - Filed January 14,
  2008Â  
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Brooks
  Roberts Fudenberg, of Charleston, and Geoffrey H. Waggoner, of Mt. Pleasant,
  for Appellant.
				Andrew
  Steven Halio, of Halio & Halio, of Charleston, for Respondent Mark
  Yampolsky.
				Todd
  W. Smyth and Neil D. Thomson, both of Haynsworth Sinkler Boyd, of Â Charleston, for Respondent Eloise Bradham.
				
				Marvin
  D. Infinger and Lydia B. Applegate, both of Haynsworth Sinkler Boyd, of Charleston, for Amicus Curiae South Carolina Medical Association.
			
		
	


CHIEF JUSTICE TOAL:Â  This is an appeal from a grant of summary judgment in favor of Respondents Dr. Mark Yampolsky and Dr. Eloise
  Bradham as to Appellant Nitus Linogâ€™s (â€œAppellantâ€) claim for medical battery.Â 
  Appellant based her claim on her purported revocation of consent to a dental
  procedure during the surgery and while under anesthesia.Â  The trial court found
  no South Carolina precedent recognizing medical battery based on withdrawal of
  consent, but ruled that even if South Carolina law permitted such a cause of
  action, Appellant failed to provide any expert testimony. Â Because we hold that
  no cause of action exists for medical battery in South Carolina, we affirm.

Factual/Procedural Background
After
  several consultations, Dr. Yampolsky, a periodontist, recommended that
  Appellant receive osseous gum surgery, a highly invasive dental procedure.Â  The
  procedure was scheduled to last approximately four hours and include all four
  quadrants of Appellantâ€™s mouth.Â  Due to her extraordinary fear of dentists,
  Appellant elected to undergo the procedure with intravenous sedation.Â  Dr.
  Bradham, an anesthesiologist, administered a combination of four anesthetic
  agents prior to and during the procedure.Â  However, Dr. Bradhamâ€™s attempt to
  sedate Appellant was not entirely successful, and the record reveals that
  Appellant would turn her head and mumble throughout surgery.Â  As a result, Dr.
  Yampolsky decided to terminate the procedure after three and a half hours and with
  only one quadrant completed.Â   
Appellant
  filed a medical malpractice action against Drs. Yampolsky and Bradham, alleging
  that she suffered a herniated disc during the procedure.Â  Discovery in the
  action proceeded, and in depositions, both doctors testified that during the
  procedure, Appellant continued to intermittently move her head and otherwise
  disrupt the procedure, thereby making the surgery more difficult to complete.Â 
  Appellant then amended her complaint to include a cause
  of action for medical battery, contending that the doctorsâ€™ deposition
  testimonies showed that she withdrew her consent during the procedure.  
Subsequently,
  Respondents filed a motion for summary judgment as to both causes of action.Â  The
  trial court granted the motion as to the medical malpractice claim based solely
  on the fact that Appellant failed to identify an expert witness who would
  testify to support her claim.Â  Additionally, the trial court granted summary
  judgment as to the medical battery claim.Â  Specifically, the trial court found
  no legal precedent in South Carolina allowing a claim for medical battery based
  on a patientâ€™s withdrawal of consent.Â  The court alternatively held that even
  if South Carolina recognized such a claim, Appellant failed to provide expert
  testimony establishing the relevant standard of care and showing that Appellant
  withdrew her consent.
We
  certified this case pursuant to Rule 204(b), SCACR, and Appellant raises the
  following issue for review:

	Did the
  trial court err in granting summary judgment regarding Appellantâ€™s medical
  battery claim?


Standard of Review
Summary judgment is appropriate where there is no genuine issue of material fact and
  it is clear that the moving party is entitled to a judgment as a matter of law.
  Â Rule 56(c), SCRCP.Â  In determining whether any triable issues of fact exist,
  the evidence and all inferences which can be reasonably drawn from the evidence
  must be viewed in the light most favorable to the nonmoving party. Â Koester
    v. Carolina Rental Ctr., 313 S.C. 490, 493, 443 S.E.2d 392, 394 (1994).Â  The
  mere fact that a case involves a novel
  issue does not render summary judgment inappropriate.Â  Houck
    v. State Farm Fire & Cas. Ins. Co., 366
  S.C. 7, 11, 620 S.E.2d 326, 329 (2005).
Law/Analysis
Appellant
  argues that South Carolina should recognize a medical battery claim based on
  revocation of consent and that expert testimony should not necessarily be
  required in proving such claim.Â  We disagree.Â   
South
  Carolina courts have specifically
  addressed issues involving informed consent in the context of medical care.Â  In Hook v. Rothstein, the court of appeals explicitly held that lack of
  informed consent cases fall under the medical malpractice framework.Â  281 S.C. 541, 553, 316 S.E.2d 690, 698 (Ct. App. 1984) (holding a patient must
  show that, based on expert testimony of the standard of care, the physician provided insufficient information to enable the
  patient to make an intelligent and informed decision).Â  Additionally,
  in Harvey v. Strickland, 350 S.C. 303, 312, 566 S.E.2d 529, 534 (2002),
  we held that South Carolina recognizes a medical malpractice claim stemming
  from lack of informed consent.
On
  the other hand, although not entirely foreign to South Carolina jurisprudence, our
  courts have not explored medical battery as thoroughly. Â In Hook, 
the court of appeals mentioned medical battery and explained â€œthe battery theory 
is applicable either where the physician performs a procedure to which the 
patient has not consented or where the patient gives permission to perform one 
type of procedure and the physician performs another.â€Â  Hook, 281 S.C. at 558, 316 S.E.2d at 700-01. Â Similarly, in both Harvey
    v. Strickland and Banks v.
      Medical University of South Carolina, we reversed the trial courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment as to the patientsâ€™ medical battery claims and noted that â€œwe have
  recognized that there may be a viable cause of
  action for medical battery as the result of failing to obtain proper consent.â€Â  Harvey, 350 S.C. at 312, 566
  S.E.2d at 534 (citing Banks, 314 S.C. 376, 444 S.E.2d 519 (1994),).Â  
 
Turning to the instant case, we must determine whether South Carolina should recognize a separate and independent cause of action for medical
  battery, or whether such theories of liability are more properly analyzed under
  alternative and well-established causes of action.Â   
Under
  our jurisprudence, an injured patient may bring a medical malpractice claim
  against a physician where the physicianâ€™s negligence in rendering medical care proximately
  causes the patientâ€™s injury.Â  Guffey
    v. Columbia/Colleton Regâ€™l Hosp., Inc., 364
  S.C. 158, 163, 612 S.E.2d 695, 697 (2005).Â  A
  patient alleging medical malpractice must provide evidence, through expert
  testimony, showing (1) the generally recognized and accepted practices and
  procedures that would be followed by average, competent practitioners in the physicianâ€™s
  field of medicine under the same or similar circumstances, and (2) that the physician
  departed from the recognized and generally accepted standards. David v. McLeod Regâ€™l Med. Ctr., 367 S.C. 242, 248, 626 S.E.2d 1,
  4 (2006).
  Â Alternatively,
  it is possible that a patient might sustain an injury as a result of a
  physicianâ€™s intentional acts that are unrelated to medical care.Â  In these
  cases, a patient may bring a civil battery claim against a physician where
  the physician commits an offensive touching outside of the medical scope.Â  Honea v. Prior, 295 S.C. 526, 369 S.E.2d 846 (Ct. App.
  1988) (upholding a jury verdict for assault and battery against a physician who
  sexually assaulted his patient). Â 
In
  light of the availability of a medical malpractice claim or a civil battery
  claim to any patient that is injured by a physician, we believe medical battery
  would constitute an unnecessary and superfluous cause of action.Â  We see little
  need to recognize an additional cause of action related to tortious injuries
  arising out of interactions with medical providers when the tort of medical
  malpractice fully covers all acts performed in relation to medical services and
  when the remaining area of private tort law applies to acts not related to
  medical services.Â  Accordingly, we
  limit the holdings of Hook, Harvey, and Banks to the
  extent that they indicate that our State recognizes medical battery and hold
  that no independent cause of action for medical battery exists in South Carolina.Â  We further hold that in order for a patient to pursue a claim
  stemming from a situation involving lack of or revocation of consent, a
  physical touching within the medical context, and a resulting injury, the
  patient must bring this claim under the medical malpractice framework.[1]Â  That is, a patient must show through expert testimony that the
  physician deviated from the relevant standard of care in failing to obtain
  proper consent, unless the subject matter lies within common knowledge. Â See David, 367
  S.C. at 248, 626 S.E.2d at 4 (holding that a
  plaintiff bringing a medical malpractice suit must provide expert testimony
  unless the subject matter lies within the ambit of common knowledge).Â  It
  is important to note that our holding in no way implies that a patient must
  produce expert testimony in a civil battery claim where the touching occurs
  outside of the medical context.Â  We believe courts are certainly able to
  distinguish between a physicianâ€™s professional services
  and acts that fall outside the medical scope.Â  See South Carolina Med. Malpractice Liab. Ins. Joint Underwriting
    Assâ€™n v. Ferry, 291
  S.C. 460, 463, 354 S.E.2d 378, 380 (1987) (holding that the
  scope of professional services does not include all forms of a physicianâ€™s
  conduct simply because he is a physician).
In
  this case, Appellant clearly sustained her alleged injuries while receiving treatment
  within the medical context, and therefore, the trial court properly analyzed Appellantâ€™s
  claim as a claim for medical malpractice.Â  Accordingly, because Appellant
  failed to produce any expert testimony that Drs. Yampolsky and Bradham deviated
  from the standard of care, we hold that the trial court properly granted
  Respondentsâ€™ motion for summary judgment. Â 
Conclusion
For the foregoing
  reasons, we affirm the trial courtâ€™s decision.
MOORE,
  WALLER, PLEICONES and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

[1]  We express serious doubts as to whether a patient could ever revoke consent to
  a medical procedure while under anesthesia or some other method of significant
  sedation.Â  For this reason expert testimony as to the standard of care ought to
  be critically important in cases of this type.
