THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				Mary Lou
      Moseley, Petitioner,
			
		
	

v.

	
		
			
				Jim Oswald, Respondent.
			
		
	


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI TO THE COURT OF 
APPEALS

Appeal from Lexington County
Â Kenneth G. Goode, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 26420
Heard December 6, 2007 - Filed January 22,
  2008
REVERSED


	
		
			
				William E. Booth III, of West Columbia, for Petitioner.
				Blaney A. Coskrey III, of Columbia, and Ralph Shealy
  Kennedy, Jr., of Batesburg-Leesville, for Respondent.
			
		
	



CHIEF
  JUSTICE TOAL:Â  In this case, Petitioner Mary Lou Moseley filed a conversion
  action against Respondent Jim Oswald.Â  The trial court granted Respondentâ€™s
  motion for summary judgment, and the court of appeals affirmed on the basis
  that Petitioner failed to present any evidence that Respondent owned the land
  on which Petitionerâ€™s chattels were stored.Â  Moseley v. Oswald, Op. No.
  2005-UP-530 (S.C. Ct. App. filed September 16, 2005).Â  This Court granted certiorari to review the court of
  appealsâ€™ decision.Â  We reverse.
Factual/Procedural
  Background
In April 1998, Oswald Wholesale Lumber, Inc. (â€œOswald
  Lumberâ€), of which Respondent is the president, purchased a large tract of land
  from Petitionerâ€™s son.Â  In October 1998, Petitioner filed a conversion action
  against Respondent alleging that Respondent refused to allow her to take
  possession of seven automobiles and various pieces of furniture stored on the
  property.Â  Respondent filed a motion for summary judgment, arguing that Oswald
  Lumber, and not Respondent individually, owned the property.Â  The trial court
  held that because Petitioner could not show that Respondent owned the property,
  there was no evidence that Respondent converted Petitionerâ€™s personal property,
  and Respondent was therefore entitled to summary judgment.Â  The court of
  appeals affirmed, holding that there was no evidence to support Petitionerâ€™s
  allegation that Respondent owned the property and that Petitioner presented no
  admissible evidence that Respondent exercised control over her personal
  property.
This Court granted
  certiorari, and Petitioner presents the following issue for review:

	Did the
  court of appeals err in affirming the trial courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment
  based on Petitionerâ€™s failure to produce evidence that Respondent owned the
  land on which her personal property was stored?


Standard of
  Review
Summary judgment is appropriate where there is no genuine issue of material fact and
  it is clear the moving party is entitled to a judgment as a matter of law. Â Rule
  56(c), SCRCP.Â  In determining whether any triable issues of fact exist, the
  evidence and all inferences which can be reasonably drawn from the evidence
  must be viewed in the light most favorable to the nonmoving party. Â Koester
    v. Carolina Rental Ctr., 313 S.C. 490, 493, 443 S.E.2d 392, 394 (1994).Â  
 

Law/Analysis
Petitioner argues that
  the court of appeals erred in affirming the trial courtâ€™s grant of summary
  judgment based on ownership of the real property on which Petitionerâ€™s personal
  property is stored.Â  We agree.
Conversion is defined as the unauthorized
  assumption in the exercise of the right of ownership over goods or personal
  chattels belonging to another to the exclusion of the ownerâ€™s rights.Â  SSI Med. Servs., Inc. v. Cox, 301
  S.C. 493, 498, 392 S.E.2d 789, 792 (1990).Â  To establish the tort of conversion, the plaintiff must establish
  either title to or right to the possession of the personal property.Â  Crane v. Citicorp Natâ€™l Servs., Inc., 313
  S.C. 70, 72, 437 S.E.2d 50, 52 (1993) (superseded by statute on
  other grounds).
In our view, the
  courts below erred in hinging their decisions on the fact that Oswald Lumber,
  and not Respondent individually, owns the property on which Petitionerâ€™s
  chattels are stored.Â  While ownership of the real property may be relevant, a
  conversion action does not depend on who owns the real property on which the automobiles
  and other items are stored.Â  Rather, the issue in a conversion action is
  whether Respondent exercised unauthorized control over Petitionerâ€™s personal
  property.Â  See SSI Med. Servs., Inc. (holding that an action for conversion may arise by some
  illegal use or misuse, or by illegal detention of anotherâ€™s chattel).
Moreover,
  the record reveals that there are several genuine issues of material fact
  regarding Petitionerâ€™s conversion claim.Â  Specifically, Petitioner produced
  evidence showing that she holds title to the automobiles and owns the
  furniture, and Respondent testified in his deposition that he attempted to sell
  one of the automobiles.Â  Furthermore, there is evidence that Respondent refused
  to allow Petitioner to retrieve the automobiles and furniture from the
  property.Â  Respondent argues that summary judgment is appropriate because a
  careful review of the record shows that Petitionerâ€™s son demanded return of the
  automobiles on behalf of Petitionerâ€™s husband and not on behalf of Petitioner
  and that Petitioner has never specifically demanded the return of the items to
  which she currently is referring.Â  We reject Respondentâ€™s argument.Â  Clearly,
  Respondent is on notice of the items that Petitioner alleges belong to her.Â  Therefore,
  we hold that the trial court erred in granting Respondentâ€™s motion for summary
  judgment.
Conclusion
For the
  foregoing reasons, we reverse the court of appealsâ€™ decision.
MOORE,
  WALLER, PLEICONES, JJ., and Acting Justice Alison Renee Lee, concur.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				Myriam Therese
      Marquez, Appellant/Respondent,
			
		
	

v.

	
		
			
				David L.
      Caudill, John Doe, David Storm, and the South Carolina Department of Social
      Services, Defendants,
				of whom David
      L. Caudill is Respondent/Appellant,
				and John Doe
      and David Storm are Respondents.
			
		
	


Appeal From Horry County
Â Robert S. Armstrong, Family Court Judge
Opinion No. 26421
Heard November 14, 2007 - Filed January
  22, 2008Â  
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Anita
  Ruth Floyd, of Conway, for appellant-respondent.
				Randall
  K. Mullins, of North Myrtle Beach, for respondent-appellant.
				Charles
  Richard Rhodes, Jr., of Conway, and Melissa Meyers Frazier, of North Myrtle Beach, Guardians Ad Litem.
			
		
	

___________
JUSTICE MOORE:Â  This is a case involving custody
  and visitation issues.Â  Amy Caudill gave
  birth to Jason in October 1992.Â  Jasonâ€™s biological father is David Storm;
  however, he has never been involved in Jasonâ€™s life.Â  When Jason was a toddler,
  Amy married respondent/appellant (hereinafter referred to as Stepfather)[1] in February 1994.Â  Amy gave birth to Kathryn (Katie) Caudill in December 1999.Â 
  Katieâ€™s father is Stepfather.
Amy committed
  suicide in September 2003.Â  A few months later, appellant/respondent
  (hereinafter referred to as Grandmother), who is Jason and Katieâ€™s biological maternal
  grandmother, filed actions seeking custody of Jason and visitation of Katie.Â 
  Jasonâ€™s biological father elected not to participate in the proceedings and he
  presented the court an affidavit of relinquishment of his parental rights and
  consent for adoption.Â  The
  family court ruled that Stepfather would
  retain custody of Jason and that he could adopt Jason.Â  Jasonâ€™s biological
  fatherâ€™s parental rights were terminated.Â  The family court also ruled that,
  pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-420(33) (Supp. 2006), Grandmother would be
  allowed visitation with both Jason and Katie.Â  Â The court further
  ruled that Grandmother must pay $25,000 in attorneyâ€™s fees to Stepfatherâ€™s attorney.Â 
  Finally, the court ruled that both Grandmother and Stepfather would equally divide the fees of the
  guardians ad litem.Â  We
  certified these appeals from the Court of Appeals.Â  We now affirm.
FACTS
Stepfather met Amy while she was pregnant with Jason.Â 
  He moved in with Amy a few months after Jasonâ€™s birth and they subsequently
  married.Â  They had a rocky relationship and separated three times.Â  Amy filed
  for divorce shortly after Katieâ€™s birth.Â  At that time, there was an agreement
  for custody wherein Katie lived with Stepfather and Jason lived with Amy.Â  They
  reconciled and then separated again in 2003.Â  Stepfather left on Amyâ€™s request
  and filed for divorce and custody of the children.Â  At that time, there was an
  agreement for joint custody.Â  While that order was in effect, Amy committed
  suicide.Â   
Grandmother
Grandmother has a
  history of depression.Â  She married her first husband at age 18 and had Amy and
  another daughter, Jessica, within two years.Â  She had a miscarriage during this
  first marriage.Â  She divorced her first husband and married her second husband
  who adopted Amy and Jessica.Â  She then gave birth to Gina and, later, another
  daughter.Â  Therefore, in six years, she had five pregnancies, four of which
  resulted in live births.Â  After her youngest child was born in 1971, she became
  depressed and attempted suicide.Â  She has periodically taken antidepressants.Â 
  She claims she has not been depressed since 1989 until the death of her
  daughter in 2003.
During her second
  marriage, Grandmother left her children in Florida in the custody of her
  husband while she attended college and law school in Maryland.Â  For three of
  those years, her children were also in Maryland.Â  She saw and talked to her
  children often while she was in school.Â  After school, all of her children
  moved back in with her.
Grandmother worked
  as a lobbyist in Washington, D.C., and later entered into private practice.Â 
  She married twice more, with her last divorce occurring in 1996.Â  In 1999, she
  moved to the state of Washington.Â  While in private practice, she started an
  internet company that failed.Â  She had to file for bankruptcy in 2001 and
  discharged $150,000 in liabilities.
Immediately before
  the family court hearing in 2005, Grandmother bought a single-family home in anticipation
  of gaining custody of Jason.Â  She wanted to be near her family for support and
  chose the home because it was in an excellent school district.Â  Grandmother has
  a net yearly income of $45,600 and testified she could financially take care of
  Jason.
Stepfather
Stepfather was in
  the Air Force for over eleven years and was honorably discharged due to
  anxiety.Â  He had one suicide attempt; however, he maintains that it was only an
  attempt to attract attention during a divorce.Â  At the time of the hearing,
  Stepfather was taking medication for anxiety.Â  He has previously taken other
  medications and, at times, would carry medicine to assist him in the event he
  had a panic attack.
Stepfather
  testified that the only time he did not take his anxiety medicine was when it
  was lost in the mail and he suffered withdrawal.Â  He then remained off the
  medicine for two years because he felt fine.Â  He alleged his doctor was aware
  of his failure to take the medicine.Â   
Several years prior
  to meeting Amy, Stepfather had a child of whom he relinquished custody.Â  He has
  maintained contact with this child, who is now an adult.
Prior to his
  separation from Amy in 2003, Stepfather met another woman, Kim Darling, on an
  adult website.Â  Within three or four months after Amyâ€™s suicide, Stepfather
  moved Jason and Katie into his girlfriendâ€™s house.Â  The girlfriend has twin
  boys that also live with them in the five bedroom home.Â  Jason and Katie call
  the girlfriend Kim, although there were allegations Stepfather was attempting
  to have the children call her Mom.Â  Stepfather and Kim have since married.Â  This
  is his fourth marriage.Â  Stepfather testified that he felt it was appropriate
  to move in with Kim because Kim helped Jason by giving him stability.Â  He admitted
  the move could have been a mistake but that it has worked out.
At the time of the
  hearing, Stepfather was working as a driver for Coca-Cola.Â  His financial
  statement indicates that his net monthly income is $2,952.
JasonJason has
  consistently had behavioral problems.Â  He was first taken to counseling at the
  age of four as a result of being expelled from four daycares in one year.Â  His
  issues included kicking, biting, and hitting.Â  His behavior was allegedly the
  result of his mother and Stepfather arguing in front of him.
Jason was admitted to
  counseling again around age six for extreme behavior problems at school.Â  He
  underwent school-based counseling and Jason indicated he had to get between Amy
  and Stepfather when they fought.
Jasonâ€™s third admission
  to counseling occurred at seven years of age and continued until 2002 when he
  was about ten years of age.Â  This service was again initiated by Amy.Â  Jason
  was in trouble at school for choking one child and pushing other children.Â 
  Jason was diagnosed with Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) and
  placed on medication.Â  He was discharged from counseling.
Jasonâ€™s fourth
  admission to counseling was initiated by Stepfather after Amyâ€™s death.Â  This
  counseling occurred between October 2003 and March 2005.Â  Jason was accused of
  destroying property and acting in a threatening manner toward others.Â  He also
  had suicidal thoughts.Â  From the questionnaire, it appeared Stepfather did not
  know a lot about Jasonâ€™s school life.Â  During the fourth counseling session, the
  Department of Social Services was called by Jasonâ€™s school in March 2004
  because Jason had been wearing the same clothes to school for a week.[2]
In October 2004, a
  therapist met with Stepfather.Â  The therapist stated Jason had made great
  progress, had less anger, and was taking Strattera for ADHD.Â  At this time,
  Jason was living with Stepfather, Katie, and Kim and her two children. In March
  2005, counseling for Jason ended because he was doing well but also mainly
  because he was resistant to participating in counseling sessions.
At one point, Jason
  was off his ADHD medication after Christmas 2004.Â  He had twelve incidents at
  school while he was off the medication.
Throughout the
  fourth counseling session, Jason vacillated between wanting to live with
  Grandmother and wanting to live with Stepfather.Â  Jason indicated that he loved
  both of them and wanted to be with both of them and that it was a hard decision
  for him.Â  He indicated that he enjoyed living with Kim and her children.Â  Jason
  refers to Stepfather as â€œDadâ€ and Stepfather is the only father figure Jason
  has ever known.Â  Grandmother admits Stepfather is a fit parent to both Jason
  and Katie and that Jason and Stepfather have emotionally bonded as father and
  son.Â  Amyâ€™s sister and other witnesses testified that the relationship of
  Stepfather and Jason is as father and son and that Stepfather loves both Jason
  and Katie.Â  The Guardians ad litem both testified that Stepfather is a
  fit parent.
Stepfather
  testified that he did not earlier seek to adopt Jason because, initially, Amy
  was receiving child support from the biological father and she did not want
  that support to stop.Â  When the support did stop, he testified they simply did
  not discuss it anymore.
A couple of months
  before the hearing, Jason was in trouble at school for choking another child.Â 
  He had also indicated he was having suicidal thoughts again.Â  Jasonâ€™s school
  records for 2005 indicated he was making Câ€™s, Dâ€™s, and Fâ€™s, and had 11 disturbing
  school infractions and one physical altercation (the choking incident).Â 
  Stepfather testified he would seek more counseling for Jason.[3]Â 
  He testified, however, that he was told by the counselor that Jason would have
  to be ready to receive counseling or it would not help him.
There was evidence that
  Stepfather favored Katie over Jason.Â  One witness testified Stepfather and
  Jasonâ€™s relationship was very reserved and cold on Stepfatherâ€™s part.Â  This
  witness felt Jason attempted to get Stepfatherâ€™s attention.Â  A former co-worker
  of Amy testified that Amy would often bring Jason to the convenience store where
  she worked.Â  Amy indicated she had to bring Jason because she did not have
  anyone to babysit him.Â  This co-worker testified that Katie stayed with her
  paternal grandparents but Jason was not allowed to do so.  
Amyâ€™s sister, Gina,
  testified that when she went to retrieve Amyâ€™s remains for the funeral in Maryland, Jason and Katie were living with their paternal grandparents at the time.Â  None
  of Jasonâ€™s belongings were inside the house because he was living outside in a
  camper.Â  Katie, on the other hand, had a bedroom filled with toys and clothes
  inside her grandparentsâ€™ house.Â  Gina further testified that Stepfather focuses
  all of his attention on Katie and does not engage in any physical contact, such
  as hugging, with Jason.Â  She mentioned that Stepfather told Jason he could not
  cry at his motherâ€™s memorial service that was held in South Carolina.
On the other hand,
  Stepfather presented two witnesses who stated Stepfather plays video games with
  Jason, that Stepfather appropriately disciplines Jason, and that Stepfather
  mostly took care of the children while Amy was alive.Â  Stepfather did most of
  the cooking and feeding of the children.Â  One of Stepfatherâ€™s witnesses stated he
  treats Katie â€œa little bit betterâ€ than Jason.
Grandmother was
  present at Jasonâ€™s birth and she saw Jason monthly until he was over 2 years
  old.Â  She did not see him in 1995.Â  From 1996 to 1999, Grandmother saw Jason
  about eleven times.Â  She did not see him in 2000.Â  From 2001 to 2003,
  Grandmother allegedly saw Jason three times.[4]Â 
  After Amyâ€™s death, she did not see Jason again until September 2004.Â  As of the
  hearing, she had seen Jason for five visits.
Katie
Katie was born in
  1999 and she and Jason are seven years apart; however, they have a good
  relationship.Â  Both Guardians testified that Jason and Katie should not be
  divided.
Grandmother was not
  present at Katieâ€™s birth and saw Katie twice between 2001 and 2003.Â  She did
  not see Katie again until after Amyâ€™s death. Â Grandmother testified that she
  could not visit Katie due to financial restraints.Â  Amyâ€™s sister, Gina,
  testified that she never visited Katie from her birth to Amyâ€™s death.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In appeals from the family court,
  the appellate court has jurisdiction to find facts in accordance with its view
  of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  Strickland v. Strickland, 375
  S.C. 76, 650 S.E.2d 465 (2007). Â This broad scope
  of review does not require the reviewing court to
  disregard the findings of the family court;
  appellate courts should be mindful that the family court, who saw and heard the witnesses, sits in a better
  position to evaluate credibility and assign comparative weight to the
  testimony.Â  Id.Â  Because the appellate court lacks the opportunity for
  direct observation of the witnesses, it should accord great deference to trial
  court findings where matters of credibility are involved.Â  Dodge v. Dodge,
  332 S.C. 401, 505 S.E.2d 344 (Ct. App. 1998).
GRANDMOTHERâ€™S APPEAL
ISSUES

	
		I. Did the family court err by
  failing to award custody of Jason to Grandmother?
		II. Did the family court err by
  awarding attorneyâ€™s fees to Stepfather?
	

DISCUSSION
I. Custody
The
  family court found that both Grandmother and Stepfather would be fit parents.Â 
  The court found that Stepfather has played an important role in rearing Jason
  and that, although he has not been the perfect father, he has been the only
  father figure that Jason has ever known.Â  The court noted that the evidence
  establishes a degree of attachment and psychological bonding as father and son.
The family court
  found that, while Stepfather has shown poor judgment by living with his fiancÃ©e
  and her two children prior to marriage, visiting pornographic websites, and not
  always taking his medication, there was no evidence that this behavior has had
  any detrimental effect on Jason.Â  The family court found that Stepfather has an
  appropriate home for Jason.
As to Grandmother,
  the family court found that she is fit to be a parent although she has had
  problems, including depression.Â  The family court noted that Grandmother was
  forced to declare bankruptcy at one point.Â  The court stated it â€œwas struck by
  her cavalier attitude to this financial experience.â€
The
  family court found that Grandmother did not have a great deal of contact with
  Jason prior to Amyâ€™s death.Â  However, he noted that she and Jason love each
  other and that Jason views her as his grandmother and not as a mother figure.
The family court
  found that it is in Jasonâ€™s best interest to be in the custody of Stepfather
  due to their relationship.Â  He also noted that he did not believe Jason should
  be separated from Katie given both guardians recommend that the children remain
  together.Â  The family court stated that Jason needs as much stability as
  possible and that Jason would find this by remaining with the only father he
  has ever known and his biological sister.
The family court
  further found that, because Stepfather has custody of Jason, Stepfatherâ€™s
  adoption of Jason should be approved.Â  The family court ordered the adoption
  although Jasonâ€™s guardian did not advocate the adoption because the guardian
  did not believe Stepfather would foster the relationship between Grandmother
  and Jason.
The best interest
  of the child is the primary and controlling consideration of the Court in all
  child custody controversies.Â  Moore v. Moore, 300 S.C. 75, 386
  S.E.2d 456 (1989).Â  There is a rebuttable presumption that it is in the best
  interest of any child to be in the custody of its biological parent.Â  Id.Â  However, in this case we do not have a biological parent seeking custody of
  Jason.Â  We have a biological maternal grandmother versus a stepfather who has
  essentially raised Jason since birth.
We recognized the
  notion of a psychological parent in Moore v. Moore, supra.Â  In Moore, a biological father attempted to regain custody of his child after a
  temporary relinquishment due to hardships from third parties.Â  We stated that
  even though there may exist a psychological parent-child relationship, the mere
  existence of such a bond is an inadequate ground to justify awarding permanent
  custody to the psychological parent.Â  We ruled that the child should be
  returned to the biological father.
The Court of
  Appeals mentioned the psychological parent doctrine in Dodge v. Dodge,
  332 S.C. 401, 505 S.E.2d 344 (Ct. App. 1998).Â  The Dodge court found
  that although the subject children had a close and loving relationship with
  their stepfather and grandparents, the level of attachment did not rise to the
  level of a psychological parent-child relationship.Â  The Dodge court
  found the family court should have awarded the biological father full custody.
In Middleton v.
  Johnson, 369 S.C. 585, 633 S.E.2d 162 (Ct. App. 2006), the Court of Appeals
  noted that, while both Moore and Dodge recognized the existence
  of the psychological parent doctrine, neither case explored how a party
  establishes that he or she is the psychological parent to a child of a fit,
  legal parent.Â  The Court of Appeals fleshed out the meaning of a psychological
  parent.Â  The court reviewed the law in other states and found that some states
  define a psychological parent by breaking down parenthood to its fundamental
  elements.Â  The court noted that in California, for example, a de facto parent is defined as a person who has been found by the court to have assumed,
  on a day-to-day basis, the role of parent, fulfilling both the childâ€™s physical
  and psychological needs for care and affection, and who has assumed that role
  for a substantial period.Â  Middleton, 369 S.C. at 595, 633 S.E.2d at 168
  (citations omitted).Â  The court noted that some states have expanded the
  definition of psychological parent, and that Wisconsin has developed a
  four-prong test for determining whether a person has become a psychological
  parent.Â  Id. at 596-597, 633 S.E.2d at 168 (citations omitted).
The Court of
  Appeals chose to adopt the four-prong test, stating that this test provides a
  good framework for determining whether a psychological parent-child
  relationship exists and that the test would ensure that a nonparentâ€™s
  eligibility for psychological parent status will be strictly limited.
The four-prong test
  states that, in order to demonstrate the existence of a psychological
  parent-child relationship, the petitioner must show:

	(1) that the biological or adoptive parent[s] consented to, and
  fostered, the petitionerâ€™s formation and establishment of a parent-like
  relationship with the child;
	(2) that the petitioner and the child lived together in the same
  household;
	(3) that the petitioner assumed obligations of parenthood by taking
  significant responsibility for the childâ€™s care, education and development,
  including contributing towards the childâ€™s support, without expectation of
  financial compensation; [and] 
	(4) that the petitioner has been in a parental role for a length of
  time sufficient to have established with the child a bonded, dependent
  relationship parental in nature.

Middleton, supra (quoting In re Custody of H.S.H.-K., 533 N.W.2d
  419, 435-36 (Wis. 1995)[5]).Â 
  The Court of Appeals discussed each prong of the test.
Regarding the first
  prong, the court noted the first factor is critical because it makes the
  biological or adoptive parent a participant in the creation of the
  psychological parentâ€™s relationship with the child.Â  This factor recognizes
  that when a legal parent invites a third party into a childâ€™s life, and that
  invitation alters a childâ€™s life by essentially providing him with another
  parent, the legal parentâ€™s rights to unilaterally sever that relationship are
  necessarily reduced.Â  Id. at 597, 633 S.E.2d at 168-169.
Regarding the
  second prong, the court stated the requirement that the psychological parent
  and the child have lived together further protects the legal parent by
  restricting the class of third parties seeking parental rights.Â  Id. at 598, 633 S.E.2d at 169.
The court stated
  that the last two prongs are the most important because they ensure both that the psychological parent assumed the responsibilities of
  parenthood and that there exists a parent-child bond between the psychological
  parent and child.Â  The psychological parent must undertake the obligations of
  parenthood by being affirmatively involved in the childâ€™s life.Â  The
  psychological parent must assume caretaking duties and provide emotional
  support for the child.Â  The Court of Appeals stated that these duties, however,
  must be done for reasons other than financial gain, which guarantees that a
  paid babysitter or nanny cannot qualify for psychological parent status.Â  The
  court further noted that when both biological parents are involved in the
  childâ€™s life, a third partyâ€™s relationship with the child could never rise to
  the level of a psychological parent, as there is no parental void in the
  childâ€™s life.Â  Id. at 598, 633 S.E.2d at 169 (citation omitted).
We find the Court
  of Appealsâ€™ adoption of the four-prong psychological parent test is
  appropriate.Â  It is a reasoned way to analyze situations such as the one
  present in the Middleton case[6] and in the instant case.[7]Â 
  It is an appropriate extension of the Moore case.[8]Â 
  As the Court of Appeals noted, the test will limit the persons who may seek to
  be considered a psychological parent, but it will assist those who are worthy
  to be called such.
Utilizing the
  four-prong test, we find Stepfather has met the requirements of a psychological
  parent.Â  The first prong is whether Amy, as the biological parent,
  consented to, and fostered, Stepfatherâ€™s formation and establishment of a
  parent-like relationship with Jason.Â  Shortly after Jasonâ€™s birth, Amy and
  Stepfather moved in together and a few months later they married.Â  Amy did not
  want Stepfather to adopt Jason because she would lose the child support she was
  receiving from the biological father.Â  After that support ceased, the issue
  either never arose again as Stepfather testified, or as the maternal family
  suggested, Amy did not wish to have Stepfather adopt Jason.Â  In any event, at
  the time of the final separation, Stepfather and Amy had agreed to joint
  custody of Jason.Â  The evidence supports a finding that Stepfather has met this
  element.
Stepfather has met
  the second prong to determine whether he is a psychological parent.Â  He and
  Jason have always lived together in the same household; that is, except for
  times of separation between he and Amy.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
 
The
  third prong is whether Stepfather has assumed obligations of parenthood by
  taking significant responsibility for Jasonâ€™s care, education and development,
  including contributing towards Jasonâ€™s support, without expectation of
  financial compensation.Â  Since Amyâ€™s death, Stepfather has clearly met this
  prong.Â  However, the evidence was not as clear as to whether he met this prong
  prior to her death.Â  Some testimony indicated Stepfather preferred Katie to
  Jason and spent his time with Katie instead of Jason.Â  The evidence also
  indicated that before her death, Amy was the person who ensured Jason received
  counseling and talked to his counselors.Â  However, other testimony indicated
  Stepfather was the one in charge of both children; that he cooked for and fed
  the children, and that he disciplined the children.Â  There is no indication in
  the evidence regarding financial support; however, given both Stepfather and
  Amy were employed, married, and all living in the same household, one can
  assume that he has provided financial support for Jason throughout his life.Â  After
  reviewing all the evidence, we find Stepfather has also met this prong.Â  
 
The fourth prong
  is whether Stepfather has been in a parental role for a length of time
  sufficient to have established with Jason a bonded, dependent, parental relationship.Â 
  The evidence that Stepfather meets this prong is clear.Â  Jason has always
  referred to Stepfather as â€œDad,â€ and Stepfather is the only father figure Jason
  has ever known.Â  Grandmother admitted that Stepfather and Jason have bonded as
  father and son.Â  Therefore,
  Stepfather has met the requirements to be considered a psychological parent to
  Jason.
Grandmother
  cannot meet the test of whether she is a psychological parent because she does
  not meet the prongs stated above.Â  It must be remembered that this is a custody
  action between a stepfather and a grandmother.Â  A biological parent is not
  involved; and therefore, there is no reason to recognize the superior rights of
  a natural parent in this case.Â  Grandmother cannot step into her daughterâ€™s
  place.Â  Although her daughter has died, Grandmother remains a third party
  seeking custody.
While
  there was evidence indicating Stepfather is not perfect and sometimes shows bad
  judgment, there is no requirement that a person be perfect in order for custody
  to be granted.Â  Because Stepfather is Jasonâ€™s psychological parent and is, in
  fact, the only father he has ever known, we find the family court appropriately
  determined that it was in Jasonâ€™s best interest for Stepfather to have custody
  of him.[9]
II. Attorneyâ€™s Fees
The
  family court found that Stepfather prevailed on a majority of the issues in
  this case, i.e. custody and adoption, and that he does not have the
  ability to pay all of the attorneyâ€™s fees he has incurred.Â  On the other hand,
  he found Grandmother, as a practicing attorney, has the ability to earn
  substantial income and has sufficient assets which she can apply towards the
  satisfaction of Stepfatherâ€™s attorneyâ€™s fees.
The court found
  that Stepfatherâ€™s attorney has been practicing law for approximately nineteen
  years and devotes a substantial portion of his practice to domestic litigation
  and that the fees he has charged are reasonable and within the norms of hourly
  rates in Horry County.Â  After a review of the factors in Glasscock v.
    Glasscock, 304 S.C. 158, 403 S.E.2d 313 (1991), the court ordered
  Grandmother to pay Stepfather $25,000 in attorneyâ€™s fees.
The decision to award attorneyâ€™s fees
  is a matter within the sound discretion of the trial
  judge and the award will not be reversed on appeal absent
  an abuse of discretion.Â  Buckley v. Shealy, 370
  S.C. 317, 635 S.E.2d 76 (2006).Â  The factors used to determine a
  reasonable attorneyâ€™s fee are:Â  (1) the
    nature, extent, and difficulty of the case; (2) the time necessarily devoted to
    the case; (3) professional standing of counsel; (4) contingency of
    compensation; (5) beneficial results obtained; (6) customary legal fees for
    similar services.Â  Glasscock v. Glasscock, supra.Â  While
  â€œcontingency of compensationâ€ is an appropriate factor considered in awarding attorneyâ€™s
  fees, the contingency to be considered is whether the party on whose behalf the
  services were rendered will be able to pay the attorneyâ€™s fee if an award is
  not made.Â  Further, the factor â€œbeneficial results obtainedâ€ merely aids in
  determining whether an award is appropriate when considering whether the
  services of a lawyer facilitated a favorable result.Â  Id.
We find the family
  court did not abuse its discretion in requiring Grandmother to pay Stepfatherâ€™s
  attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  The family courtâ€™s findings are consistent with an
  application of the Glasscock factors.Â  The family court properly noted
  that Stepfather has prevailed on a majority of the issues and that he does not
  have the ability to pay all of the attorneyâ€™s fees he has incurred.Â  Stepfatherâ€™s
  financial statement showed that almost all of his paycheck is used to pay
  bills.Â  He also testified that without his fatherâ€™s financial help he would
  have been unable to afford the litigation.
The family court
  properly found that Grandmother, as a practicing attorney, has the ability to
  earn substantial income and has sufficient assets she can apply towards the
  satisfaction of Stepfatherâ€™s attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  The family court stated it had
  reviewed the Glasscock factors and found an award should be made to
  Stepfather.Â  The family court did not abuse its discretion in awarding
  attorneyâ€™s fees to Stepfather.[10]Â  See Patel v. Patel, 359 S.C. 515, 599 S.E.2d 114 (2004)
  (an abuse of discretion occurs either when a court is controlled by some error
  of law, or where the order is based upon findings of fact lacking evidentiary
  support).
STEPFATHERâ€™S APPEAL
ISSUES

	I. Did the family court err by
  requiring a fit parent to proceed with specific grandparent visitation when the
  statute utilized is unconstitutional or is unconstitutional as applied to
  Stepfather?
	II. Did the family court err by
  requiring Stepfather to be responsible for the payment of guardian ad litem fees?Â  
	

DISCUSSION
I. Grandparent Visitation
The
  family court found that, because the adoption of Jason was approved, it would
  analyze the visitation issue as if Stepfather is the biological father of both
  children.Â  The family court found that, as we ruled in Camburn v. Smith,
  355 S.C. 574, 586 S.E.2d 565 (2003), the grandparent visitation statute could be
  applied constitutionally.Â  The family court found that, due to the particular
  facts of this case, maintaining the ties between the motherâ€™s family and the
  children present compelling and exceptional circumstances to justify ordering
  visitation with Jason and Katie.Â  After reviewing what amount of visitation is
  rationally related to achieve its stated goal of maintaining the motherâ€™s
  memory and what is in the childrenâ€™s best interest, the court specified the
  amount of visitation.Â  Grandmother was allowed two weeks of visitation during the summer
  months and one week during the Christmas holidays.Â  Grandmother was to be
  responsible for arranging all transportation and its related costs.  
Stepfather argues
  that the grandparent visitation statute, S.C. Ann. Â§ 20-7-420(A)(33), is either
  unconstitutional on its face, pursuant to Troxel v. Granville, 530 U.S.
  57 (2000), or as applied to the instant situation.Â  Section 20-7-420(A)(33)
  provides that the family court has exclusive jurisdiction to:

	order periods of visitation for the grandparents of a minor child
  where either or both parents of the minor child is or are deceased, or are
  divorced, or are living separate and apart in different habitats regardless of
  the existence of a court order or agreement, and upon a written finding that
  the visitation rights would be in the best interests of the child and would not
  interfere with the parent/child relationship.Â  In determining whether to order
  visitation for the grandparents, the court shall consider the nature of the
  relationship between the child and his grandparents prior to the filing of the
  petition or complaint.

We addressed the
  constitutionality of the grandparent visitation statute in Camburn v. Smith,
  355 S.C. 574, 586 S.E.2d 565 (2003).Â  In Camburn, we stated that it is
  well-settled that parents have a protected liberty interest in the care,
  custody, and control of their children and that this is a fundamental right
  protected by the Due Process Clause.Â  Id. at 579, 586 S.E.2d at 567
  (citing Troxel, supra).Â  We noted that, under Troxel, the
  court must give â€œspecial weightâ€ to a fit parentâ€™s decision regarding
  visitation.Â  Id.Â  A court considering grandparentsâ€™
  visitation over a parentâ€™s objection must allow a presumption that a fit
  parentâ€™s decision is in the childâ€™s best interest:

	[S]o long as a parent adequately
      cares for his or her children (i.e., is fit), there will normally be no
      reason for the State to inject itself into the private realm of the family to
      further question the ability of that parent to make the best decisions
      concerning the rearing of that parentâ€™s children.

Id. at
  579, 586 S.E.2d at 567-568 (quoting Troxel, supra).Â  Parental
  unfitness must be shown by clear and convincing evidence.Â  Id. (citations
  omitted).
The
  presumption that a fit parentâ€™s decision is in the best interest of the child
  may be overcome only by showing compelling circumstances, such as significant
  harm to the child, if visitation is not granted.Â  Id.Â  The fact
  that a child may benefit from contact with the grandparent, or that the
  parentâ€™s refusal is simply not reasonable in the courtâ€™s view, does not justify
  government interference in the parental decision. Â Id. Â In Camburn,
  we stated that, in sum, parents and grandparents are not on an equal footing in
  a contest over visitation.Â  Before visitation may
  be awarded over a parentâ€™s objection, one of two evidentiary hurdles must be
  met:Â  the parent must be shown to be unfit by clear and convincing evidence, or
  there must be evidence of compelling circumstances to overcome the presumption
  that the parental decision is in the childâ€™s best interest.Â  Id. at
  579-580, 586 S.E.2d at 568.Â  Accordingly, we have already ruled that the
  grandparent visitation statute is not facially invalid because it can be
  constitutionally applied in the appropriate circumstances.
Applying the
  statute and Camburn to the facts here, there has been no finding that
  Stepfather is unfit; in fact, Grandmotherâ€™s attorneys conceded and the family
  court found that Stepfather is a fit parent.[11]Â  We hold that a biological parentâ€™s death and an attempt to
  maintain ties with that deceased parentâ€™s family may be compelling
  circumstances justifying ordering visitation over a fit parentâ€™s objection.Â  We
  find visitation here is in the childrenâ€™s best interest to further the
  relationship between the children and the motherâ€™s family.Â  We further find the
  visitation ordered by the family court would not excessively interfere in
  Stepfatherâ€™s relationship with the children. Â Therefore, the family court did
  not err by awarding Grandmother visitation.
II. Guardian ad litem Fees
The
  family court found that both of the guardians ad litem had properly
  performed their services and were entitled to payment of their fees and
  expenses.Â  The court ruled that each party would be equally responsible for the
  balance of the fees owed to the guardians.Â  We find the family court did not
  abuse its discretion by splitting the guardian fees between the parties.Â  SeeÂ  Shirley v. Shirley, 342 S.C. 324, 536 S.E.2d 427 (Ct. App. 2000) (an award of guardian ad litem fees lies
  within the sound discretion of the trial judge and will not be disturbed on
  appeal absent an abuse of discretion).
CONCLUSION
In conclusion, we
  find Stepfather has met the requirements of being a psychological parent and,
  as such, he was properly awarded custody of Jason.Â  We find the family court
  did not err by ordering Grandmother to pay a portion of Stepfatherâ€™s attorneyâ€™s
  fees and by ordering the parties to share equally the costs of the guardian
  fees.Â  Finally, we find the family court appropriately awarded Grandmother
  visitation of the children. Â Given our disposition of
  the appeals, we find it is unnecessary to address Stepfatherâ€™s Issues V and
  VI.Â  Cf. Whiteside
    v. Cherokee County Sch. Dist. No. One, 311 S.C. 335, 428 S.E.2d 886
  (1993) (appellate court need not address remaining issue
  when resolution of prior issue is dispositive).Â  Accordingly, the decision of
  the family court is
AFFIRMED.

WALLER and
  BEATTY, JJ., concur. TOAL, C.J., concurring in part and dissenting in part in a
  separate opinion in which PLEICONES, J., concurs.
Chief Justice Toal:Â Â I agree with the majority by and large; however, I would reverse
  the portion of the family courtâ€™s order awarding Stepfather $25,000 in
  attorneysâ€™ fees.Â   
This was an extremely close case, and although
  Stepfather ultimately prevailed on the merits of the custody issue, the family
  court awarded Grandmother significant visitation rights.Â  Grandmother has
  incurred substantial expenses as a result of this litigation and, pursuant to
  the family courtâ€™s order, is now responsible for visitation costs.Â  See E.D.M. v. T.A.M., 307
  S.C. 471, 476-77, 415 S.E.2d 812, 816 (1992) (holding that in deciding whether
  to award attorneyâ€™s fees, the family court should consider the beneficial results
  obtained by counsel, the partiesâ€™ ability to pay their own fee, the respective
  financial conditions of the parties, and the effect of the fee on each partyâ€™s
  standard of living). In my opinion, it is instructive that the family
  court ordered Stepfather and Grandmother to be equally responsible for the
  guardian ad litem fees, and I would hold that the family court should
  have applied this reasoning to the issue of attorneysâ€™ fees.
Accordingly, I would reverse this portion of the
  family courtâ€™s order and hold each party responsible for his and her own
  attorneyâ€™s fees.Â   
PLEICONES, J.,
  concurs.

[1]Although
  respondent/appellant is the biological father of Katie, we will call him
  Stepfather for purposes of these appeals.Â   
[2]However,
  all other testimony indicates Jason was always well-groomed, well-dressed, and
  healthy.Â  Further, Stepfather testified that the allegations were deemed
  unfounded by DSS.  
[3]Unfortunately,
  at oral argument, counsel indicated that Jason has not received the counseling
  that he needs.  
[4]Although
  Grandmother indicated she saw Jason three times between 1999 and 2004, the
  family court found she did not see Jason from 1999 until after Amyâ€™s death in
  2003.  
[5]Cert.
  denied, Knott v. Holtzman, 516 U.S. 975 (1995).
[6]In Middleton, an ex-boyfriend brought an action seeking visitation of his
  ex-girlfriendâ€™s biological son based on the fact he had played a prominent role
  in the childâ€™s life.Â  The Court of Appeals utilized the four-prong test to find
  that Middleton was the childâ€™s psychological parent and that allowing him
  visitation was in the childâ€™s best interest.
[7]The Middleton court cautioned that its decision does not automatically give
  a psychological parent the right to demand custody in a dispute between
  the legal parent and psychological parent.Â  While Middleton was
  concerned with visitation by a psychological parent, in the instant case, a
  legal parent no longer exists.Â  In this situation, the Middleton analysis applies to a custody determination between an alleged psychological
  parent and a third party.
[8]The Moore line of cases do not apply in the instant case because Jason has
  never lived outside of his stepfatherâ€™s and parentâ€™s home for a substantial
  period of time.Â  The Moore case involves a natural parent versus a third
  party who has had possession of and cared for the child.Â  In the instant case,
  a natural parent is no longer involved and the third party, Grandmother, has
  never possessed Jason and has only had visits with him.  
[9]Regarding the family courtâ€™s decision to grant Stepfatherâ€™s
  request to adopt Jason, the family court did not err by allowing the adoption
  given the analysis above.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1820 (Supp. 2006)
  (any person may adopt his spouseâ€™s child and the requirements for doing so are
  lessened).  
[10]Stepfather
  argues the award was reasonable due to Grandmotherâ€™s dilatory tactics regarding
  discovery.Â  Twice during the hearing, the family court stated that he should
  impose sanctions given how untimely Grandmotherâ€™s responses were.  
[11]Because
  the family court properly allowed Stepfather to adopt Jason, we likewise
  address this issue as if Stepfather is the parent of Jason.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				In the Matter of W. James
      Hoffmeyer, Respondent.
			
		
	


Opinion No.Â  26422
Heard October 18, 2007 - Filed January 22, 2008Â  

DEFINITE SUSPENSION


	
		
			
				Lesley
  M. Coggiola, Disciplinary Counsel, and C. Tex Davis, Jr., both of Columbia, for Office of Disciplinary Counsel.
				Kevin
  M. Barth, of Florence, for Respondent.
			
		
	


PER CURIAM:Â  This is an attorney discipline case
  involving an inappropriate sexual relationship between James Hoffmeyer
  (respondent) and a client (Client). Â The Commission on Lawyer Conduct Full
  Panel (Panel) adopted the report of the sub-panel, which recommended a public
  reprimand.
The
  Office of Disciplinary Counsel (ODC) appeals and asks for a harsher sanction,
  contending the Panel erred in failing to find other instances of misconduct.Â 
  We agree and impose a nine month suspension.Â  In addition, respondent is to be
  charged the costs of this disciplinary proceeding.
FACTS
Respondent is a
  solo practitioner who mainly practices in the areas of criminal defense and
  insurance defense, along with a small amount of family court work.Â  In
  September 2003, Client retained respondent to represent her in a legal
  separation and child custody action.Â  Client and her husband had been
  negotiating terms without legal representation, and they were close to reaching
  an agreement when Client retained respondent as her counsel. Client, who was
  struggling with an eating disorder and depression, desired a prompt resolution
  of her case because she was concerned her husband would use her health against
  her on the issue of custody.
After
  respondent sent Clientâ€™s husband a letter enclosing proposed terms of an
  agreement, Clientâ€™s husband retained counsel to represent him on October 2,
  2003.Â  Respondent and Clientâ€™s husbandâ€™s attorney began exchanging proposals in
  an attempt to finalize the separation agreement.
Around this
  point in time in early October 2003, respondent and Client started having
  frequent telephone conversations and office visits, which were personal in
  nature and unrelated to Clientâ€™s domestic case.Â  The increasing attraction
  between respondent and Client resulted in a physical encounter on or about
  October 10, 2003.Â  Although he admitted he should not have continued to
  represent Client, respondent failed to withdraw as Clientâ€™s attorney after the
  incident and continued to negotiate on her behalf because he believed a speedy
  resolution was in Clientâ€™s best interest.
On October 14,
  2003, respondent and Client engaged in sexual intercourse at respondentâ€™s
  house.Â  Respondent discussed with Client that he should withdraw as her
  counsel, but she asked him to continue representing her, again citing her
  desire to obtain quickly an agreement in her favor.
Respondent
  continued to negotiate with Clientâ€™s husbandâ€™s counsel.Â  One of the proposed
  provisions of Clientâ€™s settlement agreement was that Client be required to pay
  her husband $3,500 for his share of the equity in the marital home.Â  Respondent
  gave Client $3,500 from his personal funds to enable Client to reach a quick
  resolution with her spouse.Â  Respondent admitted that in addition to concerns
  over Clientâ€™s medical condition, he desired to reach a prompt settlement for
  Client so there would be less of a problem spending time with Client.
In addition,
  during the early part of October 2003, Clientâ€™s eating disorder worsened, and
  her physicians recommended she be admitted to an in-patient facility in New Orleans, Louisiana.Â  Client was making plans to travel to New Orleans, and respondent
  instructed his secretary to use respondentâ€™s office credit card to purchase a
  plane ticket for Client to travel to the treatment center in New Orleans.Â 
  However, no plane ticket was purchased because the credit card had not been
  activated.Â  In addition, respondent gave Client $100.00 in cash for her
  personal use when she arrived in New Orleans.
On October 15,
  2003, one day before Client was to travel to New Orleans, respondent allowed
  Client to spend the night with him at his home.Â  Late that evening, Clientâ€™s
  husband arrived at respondentâ€™s home and confronted Client and respondent regarding
  their relationship.Â  Clientâ€™s husband took with him a tape recorder and recorded
  the exchange.
After the
  confrontation with Clientâ€™s husband on October 15, 2003, respondent told Client
  the next morning that he could not continue as her lawyer.Â  He provided her
  with names of several lawyers who could handle her case and assured Client that
  he would take care of her attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Later that day, respondent
  delivered Clientâ€™s file to another attorney, discussed Clientâ€™s case with him,
  and also assured the attorney that respondent would be financially responsible
  for Clientâ€™s legal fees.Â  Eventually, another local attorney agreed to represent
  Client and respondent paid the retainer fee.
On October 17,
  2003, respondent made a Self-Report to ODC.
Clientâ€™s
  attorney negotiated a settlement agreement on behalf of Client, which was
  approved by the family court in January 2004.Â  The agreement reached is very
  similar to the one previously negotiated by respondent, and Client received
  primary custody of the partiesâ€™ minor children.Â  Accordingly, the Panel
  concluded that respondentâ€™s personal relationship with Client did not adversely
  affect her domestic case.
The Panel did
  find that respondent violated Rule 1.7(b) and Rule 1.16 by failing to withdraw
  from representing Client as soon as it became clear that he and Client had
  developed strong personal feelings for each other.Â  The Panel concluded that ODC failed to prove by clear and convincing evidence the remaining allegations
  of misconduct in the formal charges.[1]Â 
  The only sanction recommended by the Panel was a public reprimand.
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Rule
  1.14
ODC objects to
  the Panelâ€™s failure to find that Client was under a disability as defined in
  Rule 1.14, SCRPC, and that respondentâ€™s conduct constituted a violation of Rule
  1.14.Â  We agree.
Rule 1.14(a)
  states, â€œWhen a clientâ€™s capacity to make adequately considered decisions in
  connection with a representation is diminished, whether because of minority,
  mental impairment or for some other reason, the lawyer shall, as far as
  reasonably possible, maintain a normal client-lawyer relationship with the
  client.â€
When Client
  first came to respondentâ€™s office, she was depressed, taking prescription
  medication for anxiety, and showed signs of anorexia.Â  During respondentâ€™s
  representation of Client, Client was hospitalized several times for treatment
  of dehydration and malnutrition due to anorexia.Â  These physical problems,
  coupled with the stress of going through a divorce, enhanced Clientâ€™s vulnerability.Â 
  Respondentâ€™s failure to maintain a normal relationship with his vulnerable
  client constitutes a violation of Rule 1.14.
II.Â Â Â Â Â  Rule
  1.8
ODC argues that
  the Panel erred by not finding a violation of Rule 1.8 because it deemed the
  financial assistance given to Client by respondent was merely a gift.Â  We agree.
Rule 1.8(e)
  prohibits a lawyer from providing â€œfinancial assistance to a client in connection
  with pending or contemplated litigation.â€Â  The Panel determined that the $3,500
  payment to aid Client in her divorce negotiations and the $100 cash, given by
  respondent before he withdrew as her attorney, were not prohibited by Rule
  1.8(e) because there was no expectation of repayment.
These payments,
  whether deemed to be loans or gifts, are prohibited by Rule 1.8(e).Â  Rule
  1.8(e) forbids an attorney from providing financial assistance in connection
  with pending litigation.Â  The rule does not distinguish between loans and
  gifts, and the term â€œfinancial assistanceâ€ is unambiguous and encompasses both
  loans and gifts of money.Â  See In re Strait, 343 S.C. 312, 540
  S.E.2d 460 (2000) (advancing money to client for his electric bill); In re
    Larkin, 336 S.C. 366, 520 S.E.2d 804 (1999) (providing money for mobile
  home payments for client and providing loans to numerous clients); and In re
    Mozingo, 330 S.C. 67, 497 S.E.2d 729 (1998) (furnishing money for a rental
  car to a client).Â  Accordingly, respondent violated Rule 1.8(e) when he
  provided financial assistance to Client while he represented her.
III.Â Â Â Â  Continued
  legal representation
ODC argues that
  respondent continued his legal representation of Client after he formally
  withdrew and continued a sexual relationship with Client, thereby committing a
  separate violation of Rule 1.7(b) and Rule 1.16. Â We agree.  
The record
  reflects that after formally withdrawing from the domestic action and while he
  and Client were still involved in a romantic relationship, respondent: a)
  prepared several affidavits in Clientâ€™s domestic case in August 2004; and b)
  prepared and filed a power of attorney for Client in January 2005.Â  Although
  respondent did not continue to officially represent Client in her continuous
  custody disputes with her ex-husband, we find that respondent continued to act
  as Clientâ€™s attorney while they were still physically involved with each other.Â 
  Respondentâ€™s preparation of affidavits and a power of attorney on Clientâ€™s
  behalf constitutes separate violations.
IV.Â Â Â Â  Unfitness
  to practice law/legal profession in disrepute
ODC contends
  that respondent acted with an utter lack of judgment and demonstrated an
  unfitness to practice law, which is a ground for sanctions under Rule 7(a)(5),
  Rule 413, RLDE.Â  We agree.
The record is
  replete with instances where respondent showed questionable judgment which
  demonstrates an unfitness to practice law.
First,
  respondentâ€™s behavior during the confrontation with Clientâ€™s husband on the
  night of October 15, 2003, causes us great concern.Â  Respondent belittled
  Clientâ€™s husbandâ€™s actions in regards to the separation and divorce proceedings,
  using information he obtained through his representation of Client.Â Â Â   
Another incident
  that brings the legal profession into disrepute occurred when respondent and
  Client, in anticipation of the issue arising in Clientâ€™s domestic litigation, drafted
  a synopsis of events involving their relationship up until November 2003.Â  The
  timeline trivializes certain events and makes vulgar references to Clientâ€™s private
  affairs.Â  Respondent testified that the document was a result of two people
  being â€œsilly,â€ but we believe the situation involving respondent and Client is
  far from humorous and shows questionable judgment.
Another incident
  involves an encounter between Client, respondent, and an acquaintance of
  respondent named Gigi.Â  In December 2003, respondent came home to find Client
  had intentionally cut her wrist with a knife, leaving a large gash.Â  Gigi was
  also present at the home.Â  Although there are conflicting details of the events
  of that night, a struggle ensued amongst all three, resulting in Gigi leaving
  respondentâ€™s home with a broken nose.Â   
After Gigi left
  the home, respondent expressed concerned over Clientâ€™s wrist wound and
  acknowledged the need for medical attention.Â  However, Client did not want this
  incident to be used against her in future custody disputes, so she and
  respondent avoided professional medical attention.Â  Instead of going to a
  doctor, respondent sewed up Clientâ€™s wound with seven to eight stitches while
  Client, a nurse, directed him.
Later, Gigi
  contacted respondent and informed him that she was holding him responsible for
  her injuries.Â  Respondent drafted a document, styled as a â€œComplete and Full
  Releaseâ€, which was typed by Client and provided a payment of $19,000 by
  respondent to Gigi.Â  The document provided that Gigi would hold respondent
  harmless from any liability, but it did not provide that protection to Client,
  even though Client may have been responsible for the injuries.Â  Respondent also
  failed to inform Client that she should seek independent legal advice in this
  regard.
Finally,
  respondentâ€™s judgment is called into question for not only failing to inform
  the family court of Clientâ€™s problems with substance abuse, eating disorders,
  and other self-destructive behavior, but also for affirmatively supporting
  Client in her custody dispute in August 2004 when he knew of her problems.Â  By
  filing an affidavit in support of Client, respondent let his personal feelings
  for Client get in the way of his responsibilities as an attorney and officer of
  the court.Â  His decision to get involved in a legal matter to support Clientâ€™s
  bid for custody of two small children despite her numerous problems demonstrates
  that respondentâ€™s professional judgment was seriously hampered by his personal
  feelings for Client.Â   
Aggravating and
  mitigating circumstances
The Panel did
  not make any findings of aggravating circumstances, but we believe the
  vulnerability of Client should be considered.Â  Despite their mutual attraction,
  respondent still should have recognized the vulnerability of Client.Â  She was
  under the stress of pending divorce, had just ended a recent affair, and was
  struggling with anxiety, depression, and anorexia.
The Panel found
  numerous mitigating circumstances.Â  These included the fact that respondent had
  no prior disciplinary action and self-reported, as well as the following
  evidence that respondent: participated in local mock trials at schools, spoke
  at career day, accepted numerous court appointments, participated in numerous
  legal seminars, prepared wills for soldiers leaving for Iraq, was involved in
  the Big Brother program, and donated and participated in over 16 charities and
  local fundraisers.Â  Also, respondent offered evidence from 21 character
  witnesses, who spoke in high regard of respondentâ€™s skills, diligence,
  community service, and professionalism.Â  We also note that all of respondentâ€™s
  disciplinary problems have arisen out of his relationship with Client, and
  although the violations are quite serious, we do not feel that respondentâ€™s
  behavior constitutes a continuing danger to the public.
CONCLUSION
The purpose of
  disciplinary proceedings is to protect the public and the integrity of the
  legal system.Â  In re Chastain, 340 S.C. 356, 532 S.E.2d 264 (2000).Â  In
  light of our findings of additional instances of misconduct, we suspend
  respondent from the practice of law for nine months.Â  In addition, within ninety
  (90) days of the filing of this opinion, respondent shall pay costs associated
  with this proceeding.Â  Within fifteen (15) days of the filing of this opinion,
  respondent shall file an affidavit with the Clerk of Court showing that he has
  complied with Rule 30, RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR.
DEFINITE
  SUSPENSION.
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER, PLEICONES and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

[1] We agree with the Panel that ODC did not prove by
  clear and convincing evidence the allegations of misconduct regarding: (1)
  respondentâ€™s allegedly false statements given to ODC; (2) respondentâ€™s alleged
  settlement negotiations with Clientâ€™s husband during their confrontation; (3)
  the manner in which respondent retained counsel for Client after he withdrew;
  and (4) respondentâ€™s alleged attempt to obstruct justice by â€œcoachingâ€ Client
  before her statements to ODC.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				The State, Respondent,
			
		
	

v.

	
		
			
				Ricky
      Rainwater, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Lexington County
Â Clyde N. Davis, Jr., Special Circuit
  Court Judge
Opinion No. 26423
Heard December 4, 2007 - Filed January 28,
  2008Â Â  
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Harry
  T. Heizer, of Irmo, for Appellant.
				Charles
  Hillard Sheppard, Jr., and Rachel Donald Erwin, both of Blythewood, for
  Respondent.
			
		
	


JUSTICE BEATTY:Â  Ricky Rainwater appeals the circuit courtâ€™s order finding an
  arresting officer could prosecute his driving under the influence (D.U.I.) case
  after the officer transferred to another law enforcement agency.Â  We affirm.Â Â 
 
FACTS
On August 19, 2001, Trooper Jason Stoner,
  with the South Carolina Highway Patrol, stopped Ricky Rainwater in Lexington
  County and charged him with D.U.I.Â  Stoner later left the Highway Patrol and
  accepted employment with the Lexington County Sheriffâ€™s Department.Â 
  Rainwaterâ€™s case was called for trial on June 18, 2003, and Deputy Stoner
  appeared to prosecute the case.Â  Prior to trial and prior to empaneling the
  jury, Rainwaterâ€™s attorney moved to disqualify Deputy Stoner from prosecuting
  the case because he was no longer with the Highway Patrol.Â  Deputy Stoner asked
  the magistrate whether he could call his former supervisor from the Highway
  Patrol to handle the matter, and the magistrate denied the request.Â  The
  magistrate directed the verdict for Rainwater.[1]Â   
The State filed a motion entitled, â€œMotion for New Trial,â€ arguing
  that it was error to dismiss the case because, although Stoner was no longer
  with the Highway Patrol, he could still prosecute the case as the arresting
    officer.Â  In the alternative, the State argued Stonerâ€™s former supervisor
  from the Highway Patrol could have prosecuted the case.Â  The State requested
  that the magistrate reconsider the matter and remand the case for trial.Â  After
  a hearing, the magistrate denied the motion, and the State filed a Notice of
  Appeal with the circuit court. Â 
Both
  parties eventually participated in a hearing before Judge Clyde N. Davis on June
  29, 2006.Â  After the hearing, Judge Davis reversed and remanded the matter to
  the magistrate court for trial.Â  Specifically, Judge Davis held the magistrate:Â 
  (1) erred in dismissing the case because Stoner was an arresting officer and
  could have prosecuted the case; (2) erred in dismissing the case or directing a
  verdict prior to the swearing of the jury or presentation of evidence; and (3)
  could have granted a continuance to Stoner, despite his failure to use the word
  â€œcontinuance,â€ because it was obvious what Stoner was requesting and having a
  supervisor there would allow the case to proceed.Â  Rainwater appeals.
DISCUSSION
Rainwater
  argues that the rule allowing police officers to prosecute magistrate level
  cases should be narrowly construed to mean that an officer of one agency may
  not assist another agency in the prosecution of the case.Â  We disagree.Â 
 
Three cases deal with the practice of officers prosecuting
  magistrate level cases.Â  In State v. Messervy, 258 S.C. 110, 187 S.E.2d
  524 (1972), this Court noted the impracticability of having prosecuting
  attorneys present the Stateâ€™s case in the voluminous number of traffic court
  cases, and it upheld the common law practice of allowing arresting officers to
  act as prosecutors at the summary court level.Â  Messervy, 258 S.C. at
  113, 187 S.E.2d at 525.Â  The Court noted that the officerâ€™s actions would be
  subject to the magistrateâ€™s scrutiny to ensure proper conduct.Â  Id.Â  In State ex rel McLeod v. Seaborn, 270 S.C. 696, 244 S.E.2d 317 (1978),
  the Court held the â€œprosecution of misdemeanor traffic violations in the magistratesâ€™
  courts by either the arresting officer or a supervisory officer assisting the arresting
  officer does not constitute the unlawful practice of law. . . .â€Â  Seaborn,
  270 S.C. at 699, 244 S.E.2d at 319.Â   
More
  recently, this Court declined to extend the holdings in Messervy and Seaborn.Â 
  In State v. Sossamon, 298 S.C. 72, 378 S.E.2d 259 (1989), a State
  Highway Patrol trooper appeared at the scene where county sheriffâ€™s deputies
  were arresting the Sossamons for D.U.I. and violating the open container law.Â 
  The trooper prosecuted the case, and this Court reversed the circuit courtâ€™s
  affirmance of the conviction.Â  Noting that it is practical to allow an
  arresting officer to prosecute magistrate level traffic offenses and to allow a
  supervisor to assist arresting officers, the Court found it was error to allow
  the trooper to prosecute the case because he was neither the arresting officer
  nor the supervisor of the arresting officers.Â  The Court limited the practice
  of allowing an officer to act as a prosecutor to the arresting officer and his
  supervisor.Â  Sossamon, 298 S.C. at 73, 378 S.E.2d at 260.Â   
The Sossamon court did not distinguish between the agencies, but it focused on the fact that
  the trooper prosecuting the case was neither an arresting officer nor a
  supervisor of the arresting officer.Â  By contrast, Deputy Stoner was the arresting
  officer and the person able to testify regarding the events surrounding the
  arrest.Â  Regardless of Deputy Stonerâ€™s decision to change law enforcement
  agencies, we find it was appropriate for him to prosecute the matter.Â  Thus, we
  find the circuit court correctly interpreted Sossamon as allowing Deputy
  Stoner to prosecute the D.U.I.Â  Further, because Deputy Stoner was qualified to
  prosecute the D.U.I. case, and the magistrateâ€™s decision to dismiss the matter
  caught the State by surprise, it was an abuse of discretion for the magistrate
  to deny Stonerâ€™s obvious request for a continuance in order to obtain an
  alternate person to prosecute. Â See Morris v. State, 371 S.C.
  278, 283, 639 S.E.2d 53, 56 (2006) (noting that although the reversal of the
  denial of a continuance is rare, it was clearly an abuse of discretion to deny
  the continuance because it resulted in prejudice to the appellant).
Accordingly,
  we find the circuit court was correct in its decision to reverse the
  magistrateâ€™s grant of relief and remand the matter to the magistrate for
  trial.Â   
AFFIRMED.
TOAL,
  C.J., MOORE, WALLER and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

[1]Â 
  Rainwater asserts the magistrate actually just dismissed the case, and there is
  evidence at trial that Rainwater believed the case was dismissed.Â  However, the
  oral pronouncement and the written return both state that the magistrate was granting
  a directed verdict.Â  It would be improper for the
  magistrate to grant a â€œdirected verdictâ€ based on the insufficiency of the
  evidence when no evidence had yet been presented.Â  Accordingly, we interpret
  the magistrateâ€™s order as one of dismissal.Â
