THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				The State, Respondent,
			
		
	

v.

	
		
			
				Luzenski A.
      Cottrell, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal from Horry County
Â R. Markley Dennis, Jr., Circuit Court
  Judge
Opinion No. 26424
Heard September 18, 2007 - Filed January
  28, 2008Â Â Â  
REVERSED IN PART


	
		
			
				Chief
  Appellate Defender Joseph L. Savitz, III, and Appellate Defender Kathrine H.
  Hudgins, both of South Carolina Commission on Indigent Defense, Division of
  Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for Appellant.
				Attorney
  GeneralÂ  Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh,
  Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, all of Columbia, and John
  Gregory Hembree, of Conway, for Respondent.
			
		
	


JUSTICE
  PLEICONES:Â  Appellant was convicted
  of murder, assault with intent to kill, resisting arrest with a deadly weapon,
  and grand larceny.Â  He received a death sentence for murder, the jury finding
  two statutory aggravating factors[1] and concurrent ten year sentences on the remaining three charges.Â  On appeal,
  he contends[2] the trial court erred in refusing appellantâ€™s request that the jury be charged
  voluntary manslaughter as a lesser offense of murder.Â  We agree, reverse
  appellantâ€™s murder conviction and death sentence, and remand for further proceedings.
ISSUE

	Whether
  the evidence, viewed in the light most favorable to appellant, entitled him to
  a charge on voluntary manslaughter?

FACTS/ANALYSIS
â€œVoluntary
  manslaughter is the unlawful killing of a human being in sudden heat of passion
  upon sufficient legal provocation.â€Â  State v. Cole, 338 S.C. 97, 525
  S.E.2d 511 (2000).Â  In determining whether voluntary manslaughter should be
  charged as a lesser offense of murder, the court must view the evidence in the
  light most favorable to the defendant.Â  The charge need not be given â€œwhere it
  clearly appears that there is no evidence whatsoever tending to reduce the
  crime from murder to manslaughter.â€Â  State v. Pittman, 373 S.C. 527, 647
  S.E.2d 144 (2007) (internal citation omitted).Â  We therefore review the
  evidence in the light most favorable to appellant, mindful that the charge
  request is properly rejected only where â€œthere is no evidence whatsoeverâ€ of
  the lesser offense.
Shortly after
  midnight on December 29, two automobiles pulled into a Dunkin Donuts parking
  lot in Myrtle Beach.Â  Fred Halcomb was driving one car, which contained a
  single passenger, his girlfriend Dianne.Â  Donnie Morgan was driving the second
  car; in the front passengerâ€™s seat was Donnieâ€™s fiancÃ©e, sitting behind her was
  appellant, and beside him in the back seat his girlfriend, Amber Counts.Â  At
  the store, appellant, Fred, and Dianne went in while Donnie, Amber, and
  Donnieâ€™s fiancÃ©e stayed in Donnieâ€™s car.Â  While appellant and his friends were
  in the store, two police cars pulled into the lot, and the two officers entered
  the Dunkin Donuts.Â  The officer/victim was in an excited state of mind, his
  girlfriend having just accepted his marriage proposal.Â  As the officers
  entered, appellant and his friends were talking with their acquaintance who
  worked at the shop.Â  A Dunkin Donuts patron described appellant as loud but not
  obnoxious, and testified the â€œguy behind the counter,â€ appellant, Fred, and
  Dianne were laughing a lot, but not being annoying.
When the officers
  came in the store they did not get in line to make a purchase but rather,
  according to the patron, â€œstood side by side in the entrance.â€Â  When Fred,
  Dianne, and appellant left the Dunkin Donuts carrying coffee, the officers
  followed them because, the surviving officer testified, the victim wanted to
  ask appellant some questions.Â  Appellant followed Fred and Dianne to their car,
  where he received a cup of coffee which he then took towards Donnieâ€™s car to
  give to Amber.Â  As he walked between the cars, the victim asked appellant for
  identification.Â  The other officer, who had gone to talk to Fred, observed this
  exchange and testified that the victim and appellant â€œwere just engaged in a
  regular conversation.Â  It seemed real laid back.â€Â  According to this officer,
  appellant appeared friendly, not upset or agitated.Â  The victim then â€œcalled
  inâ€ appellantâ€™s identifying information, and learned there were no warrants
  outstanding for appellantâ€™s arrest.  
Amber
  testified she then observed appellant raise his hands, at which point the
  victim pulled out his gun.Â  The victim, gun pulled, followed appellant to the
  back of the car where, Amber testified, she heard what sounded like hands being
  placed on the back of the car, followed by a single gun shot.Â  Other shots
  followed.Â  Dianne observed much the same scene, but testified the victim was
  yelling â€œfreezeâ€ as he pulled his gun on appellant.Â  Appellant then raised his
  hands.Â  According to Dianne, the officer then holstered his gun and followed
  appellant around the back of the car, grabbing appellant and getting â€œon his
  back.â€Â  Dianne clarified that the victim jumped on appellantâ€™s back, and a
  struggle ensued.Â  At this point, according to Dianne and the other officer,
  appellant shot the victim in the face with a gun appellant had on his person.Â 
  The other officer on the scene testified that at the juncture when the victim
  grabbed appellant from behind by the wrist and neck/shoulder area, appellant
  was not under arrest but remained â€œfree to leave.â€Â  He also testified that he
  heard the victim saying to appellant â€œShow me your handsâ€ as he followed
  appellant towards the back of the car, but not all witnesses testified that
  they heard this command.
After the victim
  was shot in the face at close range, the other officer and appellant exchanged
  gunfire before appellant and Amber drove off in Donnieâ€™s car. Â Donnie and his
  fiancÃ©e had escaped from the car when appellant jumped in after the shooting
  began, and Amber had moved to the driverâ€™s seat.  
The
  victim died from a combination of blood loss and a concussive injury to the
  spinal cord which the pathologist testified â€œcould certainly cause immediate
  incapacitation.â€Â  When appellant was arrested in Donnieâ€™s car later that night,
  he was found to have been shot as well.Â  The victimâ€™s gun was recovered at the
  scene, as was a cartridge from a bullet fired from that gun.Â  Based on the
  pathologistâ€™s testimony that the bullet which killed the victim may have
  rendered him instantly incapacitated, appellant contends that the jury could have
  concluded that the victim was the first to fire his gun since, had appellant
  shot him first, the victim would have lost the ability to operate his weapon.Â 
  At least two eyewitnesses, however, reported seeing appellant shoot first.
Appellantâ€™s request
  for a charge on voluntary manslaughter was predicated on this Courtâ€™s decision
  in State v. Linder, 276 S.C. 304, 278 S.E.2d 335 (1981), which held in
  part â€œThe killing [of a law enforcement officer] may be only manslaughter where
  a legal arrest is attempted in an unlawful manner, as when the passion of the
  accused is aroused by employment of unnecessary violence.â€Â  All parties agreed
  that the victim had the right to question appellant, and to ask for his
  license.Â  All agreed, as well, that appellant had the right to refuse these
  requests, a right which he did not exercise until after answering questions,
  showing his identification, and raising his hands.Â   
The parties
  and the judge disagree whether, after raising his hands as instructed by the
  officer, appellant had the right to walk away as he did, or whether, as the
  trial court ruled, at that point one must necessarily infer that the officer
  saw appellantâ€™s gun tucked in his pants, and that this observation elevated the
  officerâ€™s right to conduct a Terry stop into a basis for appellantâ€™s
  arrest.Â  The defense argued there was no evidence from which a jury could infer
  the officer had seen a gun, that is, the officer never said he saw a gun on
  appellant, nor was there evidence that when appellant raised his arms, that the
  waist of his pants (and the gun presumably tucked in it) was visible.Â 
  Appellant contended the court erred in assuming a fact not in evidence in order
  to hold that the victim had probable cause to arrest appellant as he turned and
  walked away.Â  Ultimately, the judge denied the voluntary manslaughter charge
  based on Linderâ€™s holding that a â€œlawful arrest or detentionâ€ in a
  â€œlawful mannerâ€ cannot constitute sufficient legal provocation.Â  He ruled that,
  as a matter of law, the victim acted in a lawful manner in attempting to
  effectuate the lawful arrest of appellant, whom it must be assumed the victim
  knew to be armed.  
Appellant contends
  the trial court erred, and we agree.Â  It is certainly permissible to infer, as
  did the trial judge, that the victim acted as he did because he observed a gun
  in appellantâ€™s possession.Â  On the other hand, as the defense argues, an
  alternative and reasonable inference was that the victim reacted in an
  impermissibly aggressive manner, physically assaulting and then shootingÂ 
  appellant when he exercised his constitutional right to walk away.Â  Unlike the
  trial judge, we do not find the evidence is susceptible of only one inference,
  and we hold he erred by holding that, as a matter of law, the victim was effectuating
  a lawful arrest in a lawful manner when he tackled appellant from behind.[3] The evidence in this case presented a jury
  question whether the arrest was lawful but effectuated through the victimâ€™s
  unnecessary use of violence, thereby entitling appellant to a voluntary
  manslaughter charge under Lindler.
CONCLUSION
Since the evidence,
  viewed in the light most favorable to appellant, warranted a voluntary
  manslaughter charge, appellantâ€™s murder conviction and his death sentence are
REVERSED.
MOORE, WALLER
  AND BEATTY, JJ., concur.Â  TOAL, C.J., dissenting in a separate opinion.
Chief Justice Toal:Â  I respectfully dissent.Â  I would affirm Appellantâ€™s
  conviction and hold that there is no evidence supporting a voluntary
  manslaughter charge.Â   
Voluntary manslaughter is the unlawful killing of a human being in the sudden heat of
  passion upon a sufficient legal provocation.Â  State v. Childers, 373 S.C. 367, 373, 645 S.E.2d
  233, 236 (2007).Â  In cases involving the killing of a police
  officer, the general rule is:

	A lawful arrest or detention in a lawful manner by an officer . .
  . will not constitute an adequate provocation for heat of passion reducing the
  grade of the homicide to manslaughter; nor will other lawful acts of officers
  while in the discharge of their duties constitute adequate provocation . . . The killing [of a
  police officer] may be only manslaughter where a legal arrest is attempted in
  an unlawful manner, as when the passion of the accused is aroused by the
  employment of unnecessary violence.

State v. Linder, 276 S.C. 304, 308, 278 S.E.2d 335, 337 (1981)
  (quoting 40
  C.J.S. Homicide Â§ 116 (2007)). Â However,
  â€œ[w]here there are no actions by the deceased to constitute legal provocation,
  a charge on voluntary manslaughter is not required.â€Â  State v. Wood, 362
  S.C. 135, 142, 607 S.E.2d 57, 60 (2004).
In my view, the majority errs in holding that the record
  contained evidence of sufficient legal provocation entitling Appellant to a
  voluntary manslaughter charge.Â  Specifically, I would hold that the trial court correctly ruled that there was no
  evidence that the police officer shot Appellant first. Â While the pathologist
  speculated that the bullet may have rendered the police officer
  instantly incapacitated, the record reveals that the only evidence from the
  witnesses was that Appellant fired the first shot.Â  Moreover, although Amber
  testified that she saw the police officer draw his gun and follow Appellant
  behind the car, she explicitly stated that she could not see if Appellant
  pulled a gun or who fired the first shot.[4]Â 
  Accordingly, I would hold that there was no evidence of sufficient legal
  provocation, and therefore, Appellant was not entitled to a voluntary
  manslaughter charge.  
For
  these reasons, I would hold the trial court properly refused Appellantâ€™s
  request for a voluntary manslaughter charge.  

[1] (1) Knowingly creating a great risk of death to more than one person and (2)
  murdering a police officer during the performance of his official duties.Â  S.C.
  Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-20(c)(3) and (7) (2003 and Supp. 2006).
[2] Appellantâ€™s second argument, which he conceded at oral argument is irrelevant
  to the merits of his appeal, is affirmed pursuant to Rule 220(b)(1), SCACR, and State v. Bell, 374 S.C. 136, 646 S.E.2d 888 (Ct. App. 2007).
[3] We are confident that the victimâ€™s acts are explained by his knowledge that
  appellant was a suspect in a murder case and therefore likely to be armed.Â  The
  jury, however, heard no evidence of this other crime and thus it cannot be used
  to bolster the lawfulness of appellantâ€™s detention or the victimâ€™s use of force
  in determining whether the evidence warranted a voluntary manslaughter charge.
[4] The trial court refused to give a voluntary manslaughter charge as well as a
  self-defense charge based on the trial courtâ€™s ruling that there was no
  evidence that the police officer fired the first shot.

Â THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				John and Jane
      Doe, Appellants,
			
		
	

v.

	
		
			
				Baby Girl, a
      minor under the age of fourteen years, and Birthfather, Respondents.
				Birthmother, Respondent,
			
		
	

v.

	
		
			
				John and Jane
      Doe and Baby Girl, a minor under the age of fourteen (14) years, Defendants,
				Of Whom John
      and Joe Doe are the Appellants.
			
		
	


Appeal From Richland County
Â Dorothy Jones, Family Court Judge
Opinion No. 26425
Heard November 15, 2007 - Filed January
  28, 2008Â  
REVERSED


	
		
			
				Raymond
  William Godwin, of Greenville, for Appellants.
				Robert
  L. Jackson, of Columbia, for Respondent Birthmother, and Birthfather, pro
				se, of Rockfort, Illinois.
				F.
  Earl Ellis, Jr., of Columbia, Guardian Ad Litem.
			
		
	


JUSTICE
  WALLER: In this
  interstate adoption case, appellants John and Jane Doe directly appeal from two
  South Carolina family court orders.Â  The first order dismissed appellantsâ€™
  adoption action based on jurisdictional grounds.Â  The second order enforced an Illinois decree which ordered the return of the baby girl to respondent Birthmother in Illinois.Â  We reverse.
FACTS
On June 16, 2006, Birthmother gave birth in Illinois to a
  full-term baby girl (â€œBaby Girlâ€).Â  On June 19, 2006, court proceedings were
  held in Illinois circuit court.Â  Attorney Denise Patton represented Birthmother
  who stated under oath that she intended to place Baby Girl up for adoption and
  the prospective parents resided in South Carolina.Â  Birthmother indicated she
  would be signing a South Carolina consent to adoption.Â  During the proceedings,
  she signed a â€œConsent to Guardianshipâ€ document.Â  After questioning
  Birthmother, the court waived the appointment of a guardian ad litem and
  appointed Patton guardian of Baby Girl.Â  (â€œJune Illinois Orderâ€).Â   
Also on
  June 19, 2006, Birthmother signed the following four documents:Â  (1) a
  relinquishment of parental rights; (2) a consent to jurisdiction under South Carolina law; (3) an affidavit of identification; and (4) a consent to adoption.Â  In
  the consent to jurisdiction document, Birthmother acknowledged that appellants,
  who live in South Carolina, would be filing a South Carolina petition to adopt
  Baby Girl.Â  Moreover, this choice of law document expressly stated the
  following:

	Having been informed about the law in both South Carolina and Illinois, I hereby submit to the jurisdiction of the state of South Carolina.Â  
	I agree
  that all matters relating to the adoption of my child, including, but not
  limited to the right to revoke my Relinquishment, to notice of further
  proceedings in the adoption and termination of my parental rights, shall be
    determined in accordance with the laws of the state of South Carolina.

(Emphasis added).
In the identification document, Birthmother checked a box
  indicating she did not know the identity of the biological father, yet also
  inconsistently stated the following:Â  â€œI was raped and I only knew the birth
  father through friends of friends.Â  I do not know his full name and will not
  say his first name.â€Â  In the consent to adoption, she refused to name the birth
  father, but she did state he had not supported her and had not paid any pre‑birth
  expenses.Â   
On June
  20, 2006, appellants returned to South Carolina with Baby Girl and filed an
  action for adoption in South Carolina family court.Â   
On July
  14, 2006, Birthfather filed a petition in Illinois circuit court
  requesting that the court void ab initio the June Illinois Order which
  appointed Patton guardian of Baby Girl for the purpose of transporting her to South Carolina.Â  Birthfatherâ€™s petition alleged that Birthmother knew the identity and
  whereabouts of Birthfather at all times and had told him the baby had been born
  dead.Â  Birthfather argued that because he received no notice, the Illinois court was without jurisdiction to enter the June Illinois Order.Â  Appellants were
  not named as parties in Birthfatherâ€™s petition despite the fact that they had
  physical custody of Baby Girl in South Carolina at the time.Â   
Appellants,
  however, upon finding out Birthfatherâ€™s identity, filed an amended adoption
  complaint in South Carolina family court on July 21, 2006.Â  Birthfather was
  named and referenced in the amended pleading.Â  The family court thereafter
  granted appellantsâ€™ request for an emergency hearing.Â  The hearing took place
  on July 31, 2006, and Judge Turbeville issued a temporary order on August 2,
  2006, which:Â  (1) granted temporary legal custody of Baby Girl to appellants;
  (2) vested jurisdiction in Richland County Family Court, South Carolina; and (3)
  ordered a paternity test to determine whether Birthfather was the biological
  father of Baby Girl.Â  The family court specifically noted it had reviewed
  information regarding Birthfatherâ€™s criminal history which included domestic
  violence and drug offenses.Â  In addition, the family court found that, pursuant
  to South Carolinaâ€™s Uniform Child Custody Jurisdiction Act (UCCJA), South Carolina is Baby Girlâ€™s â€œhome state,â€ and it was in the babyâ€™s best interest for South Carolina to assume jurisdiction.[1]Â Â 
  (â€œAugust S.C. Orderâ€).
On August 4, 2006, Birthmother filed a petition in Illinois circuit court to vacate her consent to adoption and have the baby returned to
  her.Â  She alleged in an affidavit that she and Birthfather began dating in
  January 2005 and were living together by September 2005.Â  In mid-October 2005,
  she filed assault charges against Birthfather, and he was arrested.Â 
  Birthmother found out she was pregnant and contacted an adoption agency, which
  put her in contact with appellants.Â  Thereafter, attorney Patton contacted her
  to assist with the adoption and told Birthmother that appellants would be
  paying Pattonâ€™s costs.Â   
According to Birthmother, she signed the consent to adoption one
  hour before 72 hours had elapsed from birth.[2]Â 
  She further stated that Patton told her if she did not list Birthfatherâ€™s name
  on the adoption papers, then he would not need to be notified.Â  Finally, she
  alleged Patton had a conflict of interest representing her.Â   
On September 8, 2006, the Illinois circuit court vacated ab
  initio the June Illinois Order which appointed Patton temporary guardian of
  Baby Girl. The Illinois court found that Birthmother intentionally failed to
  disclose Birthfatherâ€™s identity and the failure to give notice to Birthfather
  â€œdeprived the [Illinois] Court of the jurisdiction to have granted the
  guardianship.â€Â  Additionally, the Illinois court ordered the return of Baby
  Girl to Birthmother in Illinois.Â  Appellants were not named as parties
  to this Illinois matter and were not referenced in the written order.[3]Â  (â€œSeptember Illinois Orderâ€).
Thereafter, Birthfather filed a motion in South Carolina family court to vacate the August S.C. Order which awarded appellants temporary
  custody of Baby Girl.Â  A hearing was held in family court before Judge Jones on
  October 20, 2006.Â  On December 15, 2006, Judge Jones issued an order which
  found that Illinois â€œfirst exercised jurisdictionâ€ over Baby Girl at the June
  19th proceedings and â€œexercised continuing jurisdictionâ€ by vacating
  the June Illinois Order.Â  The family court further noted that a telephone
  conference was held with the presiding Illinois judge and â€œa determination was
  made that the State of Illinois is the â€˜home stateâ€™â€ of Baby Girl pursuant to South Carolinaâ€™s UCCJA. Â The order further stated that under the ICPC, S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  20-7-1980(5)(a) provides for a retention of jurisdiction.Â  Therefore, the
  family court granted Birthfatherâ€™s motion to dismiss based on a lack of subject
  matter jurisdiction.Â  (â€œDecember S.C. Orderâ€).Â   
Meanwhile,
  Birthmother had filed a custody action in South Carolina family court on
  December 7, 2006, that essentially asked the South Carolina court to enforce
  the September Illinois Order which awarded Birthmother custody of Baby Girl.Â 
  Birthmother did not name Birthfather as a party in this action.Â  Appellants
  answered and filed a counterclaim and a cross-claim, naming Birthfather as a
  party.Â  After a hearing, Judge Jones issued an order on February 13, 2007, which:
  Â (1) granted Birthmotherâ€™s request to enforce the September Illinois Order; and
  (2) dismissed appellantsâ€™ counterclaim and cross-claim.Â  Additionally, the
  family court commanded appellants to deliver Baby Girl to Birthmotherâ€™s counsel
  no later than February 23, 2007, â€œunless the Illinois court says otherwise.â€Â  (â€œFebruary
  S.C. Orderâ€).Â Â Â   
Appellants
  appealed both orders and petitioned the Court of Appeals for a writ of supersedeas to leave in force the August S.C. Order which granted appellants
  temporary custody of Baby Girl.Â  Those petitions were denied.Â  It appears from
  the record that on February 23, 2007, appellants surrendered custody Baby Girl,
  who was then over eight months old.Â   
Additional
  Procedural History
Approximately
  one month before the scheduled oral argument in this case, Birthfatherâ€™s South Carolina counsel requested to be relieved.Â  Birthfather joined in the request, and
  both filed affidavits with this Court.Â  Counsel stated she believed she had
  just cause to make the request because, inter alia, Birthfather had
  failed to pay her as agreed.Â  Birthfather stated in his affidavit that he knew
  of the hearing scheduled for November 15, 2007.Â  He then stated as follows:Â  â€œI
  understand that if I do not hire replacement counsel, the Court may presume
  that it is my intention to forfeit my rights in this matter.â€Â  The Court
  granted the motion to be relieved.Â  Birthfather did not retain replacement
  counsel and did not appear pro se at the oral argument.Â   
ISSUES

	
		
			1.
   
			Did the family court 
			err in dismissing the adoption action based on a lack of 
			jurisdiction?
 
		
		
			2. 
			Did the family court 
			err in granting full faith and credit to the September Illinois 
			Order when the Illinois proceedings were held without proper notice 
			to appellants and they were not named as parties?
		
	

DISCUSSION
Before proceeding
  to the full discussion of the legal issues, we note that this is a difficult
  case.Â  It is complicated, both factually and legally, and of course, it is an
  emotional issue for all the parties involved.Â  Most significantly, the ultimate
  decision impacts the life of a very young child.Â   
In addition, Birthfather has forfeited his rights in this matter,
  per his affidavit submitted to this Court.Â  Although he is the party who
  petitioned the Illinois court to vacate its initial order, and he is the one
  who requested that the South Carolina adoption matter be dismissed, he is no
  longer legally asserting his rights at all in this matter.
1.Â 
  Jurisdiction
Appellants
  argue that South Carolina is the appropriate jurisdiction to litigate the
  custody and adoption of Baby Girl.Â  More specifically, appellants contend that
  under applicable federal and state statutes, jurisdiction vested in South Carolina when the family court issued the August S.C. Order which gave temporary
  custody of Baby Girl to appellants.Â  Therefore, the Illinois court should not
  have issued its September Illinois Order which altered Baby Girlâ€™s custody
  status, and the family court erred in concluding that Illinois was properly
  exercising continuing jurisdiction over the custody matter.Â  We agree.
Appellants first argue that a federal statute, the Parental Kidnapping Prevention
  Act (PKPA), applies to this case and the family court
  erred in not considering its effect.
Congress
  enacted the PKPA in 1980.Â  See 28 U.S.C. Â§ 1738A (2000).Â  The primary purposes of the PKPA are to:Â  (1) promote cooperation between
  State courts so that a determination of custody is rendered in the State which
  can best decide the case in the interest of the child; (2) facilitate the enforcement of
  custody decrees of sister States; (3) discourage continuing interstate controversies over child custody in the
  interest of greater stability of home environment and of secure family
  relationships for the child; and (4)
  avoid jurisdictional competition and conflict between State courts in matters
  of child custody which have in the past resulted in the shifting of children
  from State to State with harmful effects on their well-being.Â  See PKPA,
  Pub. L. No. 96-611, Â§7(c) (1980).
The
  following relevant terms are defined by the PKPA:

	(3) â€œcustody determinationâ€ means a judgment, decree, or
  other order of a court providing for the custody of a child, and includes
  permanent and temporary orders, and initial orders and modifications;
	â€¦
	(5) â€œmodificationâ€ and â€œmodifyâ€ refer to a custody or
  visitation determination which modifies, replaces, supersedes, or otherwise is
  made subsequent to, a prior custody or visitation determination concerning the
  same child, whether made by the same court or not;
	(6) â€œperson acting as a
  parentâ€ means a person, other than a parent, who has physical custody of a
  child and who has either been awarded custody by a court or claims a right to
  custody;
	(7) â€œphysical custodyâ€ means actual possession and
  control of a child.

28
  U.S.C.A. Â§ 1738A(b). Â In addition, â€œhome Stateâ€ under the PKPA is defined as:
 

	the State in which,
  immediately preceding the time involved, the child lived with his parents, a
  parent, or a person acting as parent, for at least six consecutive months, and
    in the case of a child less than six months old, the State in which the child
    lived from birth with any of such persons. 

28 U.S.C. Â§ 1738A(b)(4)
  (emphasis added).
The PKPA is primarily concerned with when full faith
  and credit should be given to another Stateâ€™s custody determination.Â  The
  statute directs a State to enforce, and not modify, any custody
  determination made consistently with the provisions of this section by another
  State court.Â  28 U.S.C. Â§ 1738A(a).Â  A Stateâ€™s custody
  determination is consistent with the PKPA if the State had jurisdiction under
  its own law, and it was either the â€œhome Stateâ€ of child or,
  if there is no â€œhome State,â€ it is in the best interest of the child that the
  State assume jurisdiction.Â  See 28 U.S.C. Â§ 1738A(c).[4]Â   
The PKPA also provides when a State should not assume jurisdiction:

	A
  court of a State shall not exercise jurisdiction in any proceeding for a
  custody or visitation determination commenced during the pendency of a
  proceeding in a court of another State where such court of that other State
    is exercising jurisdiction consistently with the provisions of this section to
    make a custody or visitation determination.

28
  U.S.C. Â§ 1738A(g) (emphasis added).
In
  other words, when another state has already entered a custody determination
  concerning this child, the inquiry is â€œwhether the first-in time courtâ€™s
  exercise of jurisdiction was in accordance with the PKPA and whether that
  jurisdiction continues.â€Â  People ex rel. A.J.C., 88 P.3d 599, 611 (Colo. 2004). 
 
Appellantsâ€™
  argument is that the August SC Order granting them temporary custody of Baby
  Girl was consistent with the PKPA, and therefore, the September Illinois Order
  was issued in contravention of the PKPA.Â  This begs the question of whether the
  very first order issued in this case - the June Illinois Order - was a custody
  order for PKPA purposes.Â  If it was, then arguably Illinois is the
  â€œfirst-in-timeâ€ court, and the August SC Order should not have been issued.Â 
  However, in our opinion, the initial Illinois order was not a â€œcustody determinationâ€
  as that term is used in the PKPA.
First,
  we note the record reveals no â€œpleadingsâ€ for the June Illinois proceedings.Â  Likewise,
  there is no written order in the record.Â  The only evidence of the
  proceedings is the June 19th transcript.Â  From this transcript, we
  find that the purpose and result of the proceedings was a limited one - to name
  attorney Patton temporary guardian for the purpose of facilitating both the interstate
  transport of Baby Girl from Illinois to South Carolina and the subsequent South Carolina adoption.Â  Indeed, it appears that under Illinois law, such naming of a
  guardian empowers the guardian to consent to adoption.Â  See 705 Ill. Comp. Stat. Ann 405/3-30; see also 750 Ill. Comp. Stat. Ann.50/1(F) (stating
  that a child is available for adoption when a person authorized by law, other
  than the parents, has consented).
The
  PKPA clearly envisions physical custody determinations.Â  See 28 U.S.C.A.
  Â§ 1738A(b)(7).Â  In the instant case, Baby Girl never â€œlived withâ€ Patton -
  Patton simply never had physical custody of the baby.Â  Moreover, it is obvious
  from the transcript that Patton was not named guardian for the purpose of her becoming
  a â€œperson acting as a parent,â€ and Patton has never claimed a right to Baby
  Girlâ€™s custody.Â  See Â§ 1738A(b)(6).Â  Â Consequently, we find the June
  Illinois Order was not a â€œcustody determinationâ€ as that term is defined under
  the PKPA.[5]Â   
Because
  its initial order was not a custody determination, the Illinois courts simply did
  not have jurisdiction over the custody of Baby Girl prior to the South Carolina courtâ€™s exercise of jurisdiction.Â  Additionally, Illinois could not have
  â€œcontinuing jurisdictionâ€ if it never had initial jurisdiction over the custody
  matter; therefore, the Illinois court also did not have jurisdiction under the
  PKPA to issue its September Illinois Order.Â  See Â§ 1738A(d) (providing
  for continuing jurisdiction only if the custody determination originally made
  was consistent with the PKPA).Â Â   
Therefore,
  the South Carolina family court was, under the PKPA, the â€œfirst-in-timeâ€ court
  to make a custody determination when it issued the August SC Order which granted temporary legal custody of Baby
  Girl to appellants. Â People ex rel.
    A.J.C., supra.Â  The next inquiry is whether this order was issued
  properly under the PKPA.
The August
  SC Order determining custody is consistent with the PKPA if the family court
  had jurisdiction under South Carolina law, and: Â (1) South Carolina was the
  home State under the PKPA, or (2) if no home State existed at the time, it was
  in Baby Girlâ€™s best interest for South Carolina to assume jurisdiction.Â  See 28 U.S.C. Â§ 1738A(c).Â  Pursuant to the PKPA, the best
  interest of the child is met when the child and at least one contestant have a
  significant connection with the State assuming jurisdiction (other than mere
  physical presence in the State), and there is substantial evidence concerning
  the childâ€™s present or future care, protection, training, and personal
  relationships in the State assuming jurisdiction.Â  28 U.S.C. Â§
  1738A(c)(2)(B).
When
  the family court issued the August SC Order granting temporary custody to
  appellants, Baby Girl had been living with appellants in South Carolina since
  she was four days old, and appellants had filed an adoption action in South Carolina family court.Â  Because Baby Girl was born in Illinois and hence had not
  lived in South Carolina from birth, we find South Carolina cannot be considered
  Baby Girlâ€™s home State.[6]Â 
  We find, however, that it clearly was in Baby Girlâ€™s best interest to have
  South Carolina assume jurisdiction because, at that time, she had a
  significant connection to this State, and South Carolina was the only State in
  which there was evidence concerning her care and personal relationships.Â  See 28 U.S.C. Â§ 1738A(c)(2)(B).Â  Accordingly, we hold the August SC Order granting
  appellantsâ€™ temporary custody of Baby Girl was proper under the PKPA.
In
  contrast, the September Illinois Order contravened the PKPA.Â  When the Illinois court granted Birthfatherâ€™s request to vacate the guardianship proceedings and
  ordered the return of Baby Girl to Birthmother, there was already in place a South Carolina custody order.Â  Thus, we agree with appellants that the September Illinois
  Order ran afoul of the PKPA. Â See 28 U.S.C. Â§ 1738A(a) (a State shall
  not modify any custody determination made consistently with the provisions of
  this section by another State court).Â  Furthermore, under 28
  U.S.C. Â§ 1738A(g),[7] the Illinois court should not have modified the custody arrangement because
  there was an adoption action pending in South Carolina which was proceeding
  properly under the PKPA.Â  Thus, we agree with appellants that the Illinois courtâ€™s exercise of jurisdiction which modified the custody arrangement violated
  the PKPA.
Appellants
  next argue that under South Carolinaâ€™s Uniform Child Custody Jurisdiction Act
  (â€œUCCJAâ€), South Carolina is the â€œhome Stateâ€ of Baby Girl.Â  As stated above, however,
  we find that South Carolina cannot be Baby Girlâ€™s â€œhome State.â€Â  Instead, we
  find Baby Girl had no home state under either the PKPA or the UCCJA.
The Legislature passed the UCCJA in 1981.Â  See S.C. Code
  Ann. Â§ 20-7-782 et seq. (1985).Â  The stated purposes of the legislation
  are essentially the same as those listed above for the PKPA.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-784(a)(1)-(3).Â  The Court of Appeals
  has held that because an adoption action
  ultimately results in the termination of a natural parentâ€™s custody rights, an
  adoption proceeding properly falls within the ambit of the UCCJA.Â  Clark v. Gordon, 313 S.C. 240, 242-43, 437 S.E.2d 144, 145-46 (Ct. App.
  1993).
Similar to the PKPA, the UCCJA defines â€œhome Stateâ€ as:
 

	the
  state in which the child immediately preceding the time involved lived with his
  parents, a parent, or a person acting as parent, for at least six consecutive
  months, and in the case of a child less than six months old the state in which
  the child lived from birth with any of the persons mentioned. 

S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  20-7-786(5).Â  The UCCJA confers jurisdiction on the South Carolina family court
  if South Carolina is the home State of the child at
  the time of commencement of the proceeding.Â Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  20-7-788(a)(1).Â Â  In the alternative, the UCCJA allows jurisdiction if it is in
  the best interest of the child, defined similarly as in the PKPA. Â See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-788(a)(2).
Regarding
  the home State debate, courts in several jurisdictions have decided that when a
  baby who is born in one State, but within days of birth is transported to
  another State, the baby simply has no home State.Â  See, e.g., In re Zachariah K., 6 Cal.App.4th 1025 (Cal. Ct. App. 1992); Matter
    of Adoption of Baby Girl B., 867 P.2d 1074, 1080 (Kan. Ct. App. 1994); Matter of Adoption of Child by T.W.C., 636 A.2d 1083, 1088 (N.J.
  Super. Ct. 1994).Â  We agree with these jurisdictions and find that Baby Girl
  has no home State under the UCCJA. Â 
First,
  the express language of the home State definition precludes South Carolina from
  being the home State of Baby Girl. Â S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-786(5) (when the
  child is less than six months old, the home State is the State in which the
  child lived from birth).Â  Baby Girl was born in Illinois; she did not
  live in South Carolina from birth. Â Second, because Baby Girl was born in Illinois, but only remained in that State for less than four days, Illinois cannot be
  considered the home State of Baby Girl. Â Cf. In re D.S., 840
  N.E.2d 1216, 1222 (Ill. 2005) (where the Illinois Supreme Court stated
  that â€œa temporary hospital stay incident to delivery is simply insufficient to
  confer â€˜home stateâ€™ jurisdictionâ€ under the UCCJEA).Â  Accordingly, we find Baby
  Girl had no home State at the time the orders on appeal were issued.
When
  the child has no home State, the court must â€œexamine whether a sufficiently
  significant connection and substantial evidence exists to exercise jurisdiction.â€Â  In re Amberley D., 775 A.2d 1158, 1164 (Me. 2001); see also 28 U.S.C. Â§ 1738A(c)(2)(B) (jurisdiction vests if in best interest of child); S.C.
  Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-788(a)(2) (same).
We
  find that under both the PKPA and the UCCJA, the South Carolina family court had
  appropriately assumed jurisdiction when it issued the August SC Order.Â  See id.Â  Because jurisdiction was proper in South Carolina, Illinois inappropriately modified the custody determination in its September Illinois Order.
  Â See 28 U.S.C. Â§ 1738A(g); see also S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-794(a).Â  
 
In
  sum, we hold the family court erred in dismissing appellantsâ€™ adoption case
  based on a lack of jurisdiction.[8]Â 
  Under both federal and state law, the South Carolina family court had
  jurisdiction to make the custody determination found in the August SC Order.Â  
 
2.Â  Full
  Faith and Credit
Appellants
  next argue the family court erred in its February SC Order when it accorded
  full, faith and credit to the September Illinois Order.Â  Appellants maintain
  the Illinois order is flawed because they were not named as parties to the Illinois actions and were not given proper notice and an opportunity to be heard.Â  We
  agree.
The
  PKPA requires that before a custody determination is made, reasonable notice and
  opportunity to be heard shall be given to the contestants, any parent whose
  parental rights have not been previously terminated, and any person who has
  physical custody of a child.Â  28 U.S.C. Â§ 1738A(e); see also S.C.
  Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-790 (providing the same requirements under the UCCJA).  
 â€œThe purpose of the UCCJA requiring notice is to preserve the fairness of the hearing.â€Â  Clark v. Gordon, 313 S.C. 240, 246, 437 S.E.2d 144, 147 (Ct. App. 1993).Â 
  Put simply, the family court must â€œâ€˜afford full faith and credit to custody
  orders of other states only if those orders are competently entered in
  accordance with standards set forth inâ€™â€ the UCCJA. Â Id. at 245, 437
  S.E.2d at 147 (Ct. App. 1993) (quoting Purdie v. Smalls, 293
  S.C. 216, 222, 359 S.E.2d 306, 309 (Ct. App. 1987)) (emphasis added).Â  In other
  words, â€œjudgments obtained in violation of procedural
  due process are not entitled to full faith and credit when sued upon in another
  jurisdiction.â€ Â Purdie v. Smalls, 293 S.C. at 220, 359 S.E.2d at 308.
Here,
  it is clear from the face of the Illinois pleadings appellants were never named
  as parties despite the fact that they had physical custody of Baby Girl.Â  This
  is a patent violation of both federal and state law.Â  See 28 U.S.C. Â§
  1738A(e); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-790.  
Moreover,
  although appellants received indirect notice of the Illinois hearing and
  retained an attorney to enter a special appearance, they were never officially
  served notice of the hearing and were not provided with copies of the
  pleadings.Â  Respondents contend that because appellants admit they had actual
  notice and made an appearance, their due process rights were protected.Â  We
  disagree.Â  Where there is not even an attempt at service of process, the notice
  requirements of the PKPA are not met, and actual notice is insufficient to
  confer personal jurisdiction. Â See Ex parte D.B., ___ So.2d
  ___, 2007 WL 1723618, *12-13 (Ala. 2007).
In
  the instant case, appellants were consistently excluded as parties from the Illinois pleadings filed by both Birthfather and Birthmother.Â  This was unfair to
  appellants who, at the time, had physical custody of Baby Girl.Â  We find appellantsâ€™
  due process rights were compromised in the resulting Illinois court proceedings,
  and therefore, South Carolina is not bound by the September Illinois Order.Â  Clark v. Gordon, supra (judgments obtained
  in violation of procedural due process are not entitled to full faith and
  credit).
Accordingly,
  we hold the family court erred in issuing its February SC Order which enforced
  the September Illinois Order awarding custody to Birthmother.Â   
CONCLUSION
For
  the reasons discussed above, we reverse the family court orders which dismissed
  appellantsâ€™ adoption action and enforced the Illinois custody award to
  Birthmother.Â  Accordingly, we reinstate: Â (1) the August SC Order awarding custody
  of Baby Girl to appellants, and (2) appellantsâ€™ adoption action.Â  Furthermore,
  we order Birthmother to return Baby Girl to appellants within fifteen (15) days of the date of this opinion.Â 
  This matter is remanded to the family court for further proceedings consistent
  with our decision.
REVERSED AND REMANDED.
MOORE, A.C.J., PLEICONES, BEATTY, JJ., and Acting Justice J.
  Ernest Kinard, Jr., concur.

[1] Birthfather had notice of this emergency hearing, but
  his South Carolina counsel arrived too late to participate.Â  Counsel then filed
  a Rule 59(e) motion to reconsider.Â  The family court denied the motion on
  October 14, 2006, because appellants did not receive timely notice of the
  motion.  
[2] Birthmotherâ€™s allegation appears to be that Illinois law requires that 72 hours elapse prior to consenting to adoption.Â 
  At the June 19th hearing, however, Birthmother stated under oath
  that she was consenting to adoption by a South Carolina couple, and also her
  consent to that adoption was going to be memorialized as a consent under South Carolina law.Â  In the Consent to Jurisdiction that she signed on June 19th,
  Birthmother stated the following:
I
  have been advised that under South Carolina law, my Relinquishment can be
  signed anytime after the birth of the child and that my Relinquishment is
  irrevocable upon signing.Â  I have been advised that I may challenge the
  validity of my Relinquishment only by filing a petition in South Carolina
  alleging fraud, coercion, duress, or that I did not sign the Relinquishment
  voluntarily and that my childâ€™s best interest would be served by being removed
  from the care of the adoptive parents.
This is an accurate
  summary of the applicable South Carolina law, under which there is no waiting
  period required prior to signing a relinquishment for purposes of adoption. Â See S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 20-7-1700 through 1720 (Supp.
  2006).Â   
[3] According to Respondentsâ€™
  brief, appellants received notice of the hearing and made a special appearance
  to object to jurisdiction.Â  However, according to appellantsâ€™ brief, they
  received only â€œindirect noticeâ€ of the Illinois proceedings.Â  While they
  retained Illinois counsel to enter a special appearance to contest
  jurisdiction, appellants claim they were never provided with copies of the
  pleadings to vacate the guardianship.Â   
[4] See also Greg Waller, Note, When
  The Rules Donâ€™t Fit The Game:Â  Application Of The Uniform Child Custody
  Jurisdiction Act And The Parental Kidnaping Prevention Act To Interstate
  Adoption Proceedings, 33 Harv. J. on Legis. 271, 282 (1996) (Under the
  PKPA, preference is given to â€œhome stateâ€ jurisdiction, but â€œbest interestâ€
  jurisdiction may be asserted when no other state qualifies as the childâ€™s â€œhome
  stateâ€) (hereinafter â€œWhen The Rules Donâ€™t Fit The Gameâ€).
[5] We recognize that many guardianship orders may indeed
  be custody determinations subject to the PKPA, but only when those orders truly
  confer custody of the child on the named guardian.Â  See, e.g., Jackson
    v. Hendricks, 893 A.2d 292 (Vt. 2005) (where the case involved a
  Vermont family courtâ€™s modification of an existing custody determination which
  was a Connecticut order awarding legal guardianship, i.e. custody, of the child
  to his maternal grandmother).Â  It is clear, however, that the Illinois
  â€œguardianshipâ€ in the instant case is distinct from a guardianship which awards
  custody.  
[6] The â€œhome Stateâ€ concept will be discussed more fully infra.
[7] Section 1738A(g) states that a State court shall not exercise jurisdiction in any proceeding for
  a custody determination that is â€œcommenced during the pendency of a proceeding
  in a court of another State where such court of that other State is exercising
  jurisdiction consistently withâ€ the PKPA.
[8] We note the family court also erred in finding that
  pursuant to the ICPC, Illinois had jurisdiction in this case.Â  While the ICPC
  does state that the â€œsending agency shall retain jurisdiction over the child
  sufficient to determine all matters in relation to the custody â€¦ of the child
  which it would have had if the child had remained in the sending agencyâ€™s
  state, until the child is adopted,â€ S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1980 (1985), we find
  this section was not meant to trump both the federal (PKPA) and state (UCCJA)
  statutory sections more specifically related to conferring jurisdiction.Â  See When The Rules Donâ€™t Fit The Game, 33 Harv. J. on Legis. at 288 n.76 (â€œSince a court is only one of many parties that may be a
  â€˜sending agencyâ€™ under the ICPC, â€˜jurisdictionâ€™ arguably has a different
  meaning under the ICPC than under the UCCJA and PKPA.â€).Â  Moreover, we note the
  ICPC was designed to ensure that placements for children
  across state lines are safe; it was not designed to protect the rights of the
  birth parents.Â  In re Adoption/Guardianship No. 3598, 701 A.2d 110, 121
  (Md. 1997). Â Certainly, there was no evidence that Baby Girlâ€™s placement with
  appellants had become unsafe in any way.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				In the Matter
      of O. Lee Sturkey, Respondent.
			
		
	


Opinion No. 26426
Heard December 5, 2007 - Filed January 28,
  2008
DEFINITE SUSPENSION


	
		
			
				Lesley M. Coggiola, Disciplinary Counsel, and Barbara M. Seymour, Assistant
  Deputy Disciplinary Counsel, both of Columbia; for the Office of Disciplinary
  Counsel.
				C. Rauch Wise, of Greenwood; for Respondent.
			
		
	


PER CURIAM: Â In
  this attorney disciplinary matter, the Office of Disciplinary Counsel (ODC) filed
  formal charges against respondent, O. Lee Sturkey, alleging misconduct in eight
  different criminal matters.Â  Sturkey failed to answer, and he was found to be
  in default.Â  After a hearing, both the sub-panel and the full panel of the
  Commission on Lawyer Conduct recommended that respondent be sanctioned with: Â a
  nine-month definite suspension; mandatory compliance with a law office
  management assistance program as a condition of reinstatement; and payment of
  costs of the proceedings.Â  We impose the recommended sanction.Â  However, we
  address ODCâ€™s argument on appeal that the Commission erred in allowing certain
  evidence to be considered in mitigation without giving ODC the opportunity to
  present counter-testimony.Â   
FACTS
Respondent, the part-time public defender
  for McCormick, Edgefield, and Saluda counties, had a caseload averaging more
  than 700 cases per year.Â  Eight complaints against him by clients or spouses of
  clients were received by ODC.Â  Respondent failed to respond to the formal
  charges, and he was held in default.Â  The factual allegations regarding the
  eight matters, as admitted by virtue of respondentâ€™s default, are as follows:Â 
  (1) ODC received a complaint from Client A alleging respondent failed to
  adequately represent him in a criminal matter; (2) ODC received a complaint
  from Client B alleging respondent failed to adequately communicate with him
  regarding a criminal matter and that he failed to appear in court; (3) ODC
  received a complaint from Client C alleging respondent failed to pursue his
  clientâ€™s objectives and failed to adequately communicate with him about his
  criminal case; (4) ODC received a complaint from Client D alleging respondent
  failed to pursue his objectives in his criminal matter; (5) ODC received a
  complaint from Client E alleging respondent failed to provide him with
  information and documents he requested relating to his criminal case; (6) ODC
  received a complaint from Client F alleging respondent failed to adequately
  communicate with him about his criminal case; (7) ODC received a complaint from
  Client G alleging respondent failed to diligently pursue his criminal case and
  failed to respond to his calls and letters; and (8) ODC received a complaint
  from the husband of Client H, alleging respondent engaged in confidential
  conversations with Client H in front of law enforcement officers and respondent
  failed to provide her with competent and diligent representation.Â  Respondent
  failed to: Â comply with ODCâ€™s initial requests to respond to the complaints of
  Client A and Client B;Â  respond to the request for a written response in all
  eight matters; and provide additional information requested by ODC, including
  client files, in regard to Client A, Client B, Client F, and Client G.  
The Hearing
Because
  respondent admitted the factual allegations by virtue of his default, a hearing
  was held before the sub-panel solely for the purpose of recommending an
  appropriate sanction.Â  Despite the fact that respondent only gave ODC notice of
  witnesses via telephone two days before the hearing, ODC did not object to the
  presentation of respondentâ€™s mitigation witnesses.Â  One of the witnesses was
  Ervin Maye, the assistant solicitor in charge of McCormick, Edgefield, and Saluda counties.Â  In addition to testifying favorably about his observations of respondentâ€™s
  skills as a trial lawyer and character, Maye began to testify regarding the favorable
  disposition of some of the criminal matters against the complainants.Â  ODC
  objected to any testimony regarding the underlying criminal matters, arguing
  they were deemed admitted by default and any testimony regarding lack of harm
  would have no bearing on the case.Â  The sub-panel allowed the testimony,
  limited to whether a client was harmed, and denied ODCâ€™s request for a
  continuance in order to call the complainants to testify to counter the
  information.Â   
After Mayeâ€™s testimony regarding the outcome of some of the
  matters, ODC renewed its objection to the consideration of the outcome of the
  clientsâ€™ cases in determining harm because they were not given notice of the
  purpose of Mayeâ€™s testimony such that they could present counter testimony
  regarding harm to clients.Â  The sub-panel ultimately denied the motion, stating
  it considered all the matters from the complaint deemed admitted via
  respondentâ€™s default.Â   
After
  presenting the testimony of another character witness, respondent testified.Â 
  Respondent stated he had a large caseload as a public defender, but he could
  not explain his failure to respond to ODCâ€™s requests other than being
  completely overwhelmed.Â  Over ODCâ€™s objections, respondent also testified
  regarding the favorable outcomes of the cases involving Clients B, C, D, E, F,
  and H.Â   
After the hearing, the sub-panel found respondent engaged in
  misconduct in violation of:Â  Rule 7(a)(1) of the Rules for Lawyer Disciplinary
  Enforcement, Rule 413, SCACR (violating a Rule of Professional Conduct); Rule
  7(a)(3) (willful failure to comply with a subpoena or knowing failure to
  respond to a lawful demand from a disciplinary authority); and Rule 7(a)(5)
  (conduct tending to pollute the administration of justice or bringing the legal
  profession into disrepute).Â  With regard to the specific matters before the
  sub-panel, it found respondent violated the following rules:

	(1) Rule 1.4, RPC (failure to communicate with a client) with
  regard to Clients B, C, E, F, and G;
	(2) Rule 1.2, RPC (failure to pursue clientâ€™s objectives and scope
  of representation) in the matters involving Clients C and D;
	(3) Rule 1.3, RPC (failure to represent with due diligence) with
  regard to Clients G and H; and
	(4) Rule 1.1, RPC (competence), and Rule 1.6 (confidentiality)
  with regard to Client H. 

The sub-panel considered as aggravating factors:Â  (1) respondentâ€™s
  prior disciplinary history and failure to comply with the requirement that he
  change the way he ran his office; (2) his pattern of misconduct and multiple
  offenses; (3) his failure to respond to or cooperate with ODC; and (4) his
  substantial experience practicing law.Â  The sub-panel considered as mitigating
  factors the evidence of respondentâ€™s good character and abilities as a trial
  lawyer.Â  With regard to the evidence that there was no harm to clients, the sub-panel
  stated:

	We recognize that client harm is a subjective factor difficult to
  measure when clients plead guilty, but we do consider the apparent lack of harm
  as a mitigating factor for which we give appropriate weight in our discretion
  as a panel.Â  As a result of Respondentâ€™s failure to answer the formal charges,
  it is undisputed that Respondent failed to adequately communicate with his
  clients in the [Client B], [Client C], [Client E], [Client F], and [Client G]
  matters; that he failed to adequately pursue his clientsâ€™ objectives in the [Client
  C] and [Client D] matters; that he failed to diligently pursue his clientsâ€™
  cases in the [Client G] and [Client H] matters, and, that he failed to
  competently represent [Client H] and revealed confidential information in her
  case.Â  The facts that these clients ultimately plead [sic] guilty to lesser
  offenses than those with which they were originally charged and that the
  solicitor believes these were good results are given slight consideration in
  our recommendation, due to the difficulty in measuring harm under such
  circumstances.Â  

The sub-panel gave some consideration to respondentâ€™s heavy
  caseload and the systematic problems with the public defender system, but it
  found respondent still had the obligation to only accept as many cases as he
  could ethically handle.Â  The sub-panel noted that, at a minimum, respondent
  should have adopted the case and office management systems introduced to him
  during his participation in LOMAP pursuant to his 2000 disciplinary sanction.Â 
  Finally, the sub-panel noted respondentâ€™s large caseload and the lack of harm
  to clients did not excuse his failure to respond to or communicate with his
  clients.Â  After considering all of these matters, the sub-panel recommended respondent
  be sanctioned with a definite suspension of nine months, required to
  participate in a law office management assistance program, and pay the costs of
  the proceedings.Â   
Over ODCâ€™s objection that it was error for the sub-panel to
  consider Mayeâ€™s testimony of a favorable result as evidence of no harm to
  clients, the full panel adopted the sub-panelâ€™s report and recommendation.Â  ODC
  appeals.
DISCUSSION
Neither ODC nor Sturkey complain about the recommended sanction. Â Sturkeyâ€™s failure to
  communicate with his clients, failure to pursue their objectives, and failure
  to respond to ODC inquiries and requests to answer or provide documentation
  regarding the eight matters are serious offenses.Â  Considering Sturkeyâ€™s
  failure to adequately communicate with his clients and complete disregard for
  the disciplinary process, we agree with the Commission that Sturkey violated
  the Rules of Professional Conduct and, thus, there are grounds for discipline
  in this case. Â See Rule
  1.1, RPC (competence); Rule 1.2, RPC (failure to pursue clientâ€™s objectives and
  scope of representation); Rule 1.3, RPC (failure to represent with due
  diligence); Rule 1.4, RPC (failure to communicate with a client); and Rule 1.6
  (confidentiality); Rule 7(a)(1), RLDE (violating a Rule of Professional
  Conduct); Rule 7(a)(3), RLDE (willful failure to comply with a subpoena or
  knowing failure to respond to a lawful demand from a disciplinary authority);
  and Rule 7(a)(5), RLDE (conduct tending to pollute the administration of
  justice or bringing the legal profession into disrepute).Â   
Because of the seriousness of his offenses, we find the Commissionâ€™s
  recommendation of a nine-month suspension, mandatory compliance with a law
  office management assistance program, and payment of costs is appropriate.Â  See In re Strait, 343 S.C. 312, 540 S.E.2d 460 (2000) (sanctioning attorney
  to a six-month and one day suspension for:Â  failing to act diligently; failing
  to return client phone calls; failing to inform client of dismissal of case;
  failing to return client materials; and failing to timely respond to ODC
  correspondence); In re Shibley, 337 S.C. 50, 522 S.E.2d 812 (1999)
  (sanctioning attorney to a two-year suspension for:Â  failing to represent
  client diligently, promptly, and competently; failing to keep client informed
  about the status of the case; terminating representation without taking steps
  to protect clientâ€™s interest; violating a valid court order; and failing to
  cooperate with the ODC investigation); In re Matson, 333 S.C. 242, 509
  S.E.2d 263 (1998) (sanctioning attorney to a definite suspension for eighteen
  months for:Â  neglect of legal matters; failure to communicate with clients;
  failure to protect clientsâ€™ interests when terminating representation; and
  failure to cooperate with ODC).Â  Â 
However, ODC complains that the Commission should not have considered the testimony
  regarding the final disposition of the complainantsâ€™ cases as evidence of lack
  of harm in mitigation without allowing ODC the opportunity to present
  counter-evidence.Â  We agree.  
Generally,
  parties to disciplinary proceedings are required to exchange witness lists
  within twenty days of filing the answer.Â  Rule 25(a), RLDE.Â  The parties also
  must exchange documents and witness statements to be presented at the hearing.Â 
  Rule 25(b)(1), RLDE.Â  Where a party fails to timely disclose witness names or
  statements as required by the rules, the sub-panel or hearing officer may
  â€œgrant a continuance of the hearing, preclude the party from calling the
  witness or introducing the document, or take such other action as may be
  appropriate.â€Â  Rule 25(g), RLDE.Â   
ODC did
  not object to respondent presenting witnesses in mitigation, despite the fact
  that he defaulted, failed to cooperate in general, and failed to give
  sufficient prior notice of the witnesses.Â  Mayeâ€™s mitigating testimony
  regarding the ultimate outcome of the complainantsâ€™ cases touched on more substantive
  matters than the usual mitigation testimony regarding the respondentâ€™s
  character and personal situation.Â  Lack of harm, similar to lack of prejudice,
  may be considered as mitigating evidence in a disciplinary action.Â  In re
    McFarland, 360 S.C. 101, 105, 600 S.E.2d 537, 539 (2004) (considering the
  lack of prejudice to the clientâ€™s case as a mitigating factor).Â  However,
  considering the surprise nature of the lack of harm evidence presented in this
  default case, it should have been considered in conjunction with rebuttal
  evidence showing actual harm.Â  Despite the Commissionâ€™s finding that it did not
  give much weight to the lack of harm evidence, we find the Commission abused
  its discretion in denying the continuance because it did not allow ODC the
  opportunity to obtain and present evidence to rebut the surprise lack of harm
  evidence.Â   
We agree with the parties that a nine-month suspension, with
  participation in a law office management program and payment of costs, is the
  appropriate sanction for respondent.Â  We caution the Commission in the future
  to carefully weigh the continuance decision when, as in the present case, the
  parties present surprise evidence without prior notice to the obvious
  disadvantage of the other party.Â   
DEFINITE
  SUSPENSION.
TOAL,
  C.J., MOORE, WALLER, PLEICONES and BEATTY, JJ., concur.
